They have an outdoor space as well, for smoking. A DJ started playing after 8; one of the servers told me they have live bands on Thursdays and Fridays. I loved the varied seating, they have kept all group sizes in mind.
I tried their signature cocktails: Are You In Cal, I've never had Alpenliebe washed vodka before, but it went well with caramel, coffee and spiced milk liqueur; Hello Stranger, Matcha went fantastic with coconut milk and Japanese whiskey, especially the Matcha wafer; Friday, 7 PM, gondhoraj was matched cleverly with gin and vermouth; For Old Times Sake, gin and amaro go well especially when sesame and coconut oil are involved; Dude, Put Your Shirt On, I've never had scotch paired with Kulfi, but the subtlety paid off; The Stage Is Set, sake, red cabbage tequila, aloe vera and olive brine is a mixture I've never had before, was a bit salty for my taste but not bad; Pop Goes The Daisy, coriander oil and gherkin aren't usual ingredients for a cocktail but with tequila they went really well. I loved the way they had presented their cocktail menu, each item had a small backstory leading up to its name.
We tried the small plates as well: Silk Road Seekh, Stir Fried Crispy Hunan Chicken, Spicy Chicken and Leek; they were all pretty good.
We finished up with the Dark Chocolate Tart and it was simply delicious.
The prices are quite high but that's to be expected from a place like this. I would highly recommend this place. Needless to say, we were just a little bit sober when we left!

We walked in just to have one drink, but did that change! We ended up trying nearly every cocktail!!

We absolutely loved the drinks, and the food! Abhishek and Gyan were so kind and helpful, explaining the concept of each drink and taking thr time to understand what kind of flavors we like and suggesting amazing drinks for us!

By far our favorite bar in Calcutta! Really looking forward to coming back again next time we visit!

By far.. the best place I‚Äôve been to in the city! It has it all.. just give it some time and it will amaze you! The vibe is top notch! Let me start with drinks.. so they call it ‚Äòthe cocktail bar‚Äô and rightly so.. it definitely is! They have a vast range and all of them has uniqueness to them! Food is great!
Ambience is amazing. Inside as well as outside. Decor is just fab. Staff personally pays attention to you and well they do understand your taste I think.
All and all.. it‚Äôs a great great place with an amazing vibe! If you gotta party.. think no more! Trust me on that!

The place is awesome with great live music playing. The cocktails are lovely. The Beijing lamb is a must try. The staffs member are friendly and very courteous with great knowledge of the food and drinks they are serving. Shantanu, Michael Shantanu and Debashish made the experience even better with their hospitality.

Great food and ambience. Had a sour experience while making the reservation. Requested the manager that we are visiting on a special occassion. He did not bother to enquire any details from us nor our names. Giving 2 stars for the service in the lounge which was good.

placeMetadata.name: The Bhawanipur House

sources.shortName: The New Generation of Entrepreneurs Giving Kolkata‚Äôs Heritage Buildings a Fresh Start

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled in the quiet streets of Bhawanipur, The Bhawanipur House is a 150-year-old heritage bungalow that was once owned by the Ghosh family and has now been transformed into a popular cafe by the Prakash Group. The cafe offers a unique blend of classic charm and modern gastronomy, with gourmet-style food served in an Instagrammable setting. The multiple rooms provide various seating options, each exuding a classic ambiance with tasteful decor.
placeMetadata.address: 13/1B, Priyanath Mallick Rd, Bakul Bagan, Bhowanipore, Kolkata, West Bengal 700026, India

reviews.reviewText: It‚Äôs so beautiful and aesthetically done - probably a former mansion/home that‚Äôs been renovated across several floors into a unique coffee shop. There is a lounge on the ground floor, cafe on the first and terrace. They have provisions for events and private parties. The food and coffee and great. They host numerous interestingly curated events including coffee raves

The ambiance is quite nice, with plenty of seating options both indoors and outdoors, making it a comfortable place to relax. The staff was well-behaved and attentive, ensuring a smooth experience.

The food was tasty, but the portion sizes felt small compared to the high prices. Additionally, the coffee was over-extracted, likely due to old beans, and there was no cappuccino option on the menu. It would be great if they introduced more caf√©-style items like croissants and brownies, which pair well with coffee. A complimentary cookie with coffee would also enhance the experience.

A few improvements could be made, such as adding a washbasin on the first floor for convenience and serving cutlery with meals. Introducing gluten-free options in the menu would also be a welcome addition.

Overall, a good place with potential, but a few refinements would make it even better.
Nice place for dating  with ur loved ones. ordered two cup mocha coffee and pizza pollo lazio.  Coffee and pizza both was good. Price was quite high. Staffs are courteous. Overall nice experience.

Undoubtedly the place is super luxurious and give you Indo-westen vibe from inside out. Very airy ambience Plenty sitting area. Coming to food it's a bit costly but taste was nice. Service and stuffs over there were very polite. Definitely go for it.

We tried chicken a-la-kiev in the main course that was good but the smashed potato was not tasty. We also had starter fish n chips that was ok ok and the broccoli soup one was not good . We didn't eat . Overall we experienced not anything so tasty . And all are overpriced.
A good venue for catch up with friends. The ambience was great and the staff were discreet and knowledgeable. The renovation has been done exceedingly well, you feel like exploring Bhawanipur house.
The Ambience is great.. Ideal for heritage lovers, insta‚Äëworthy photo ops, casual adda, or quiet tea/coffee breaks.

A perfect blend of classic vibes with modern gastronomy. Loved the way they have conserved a heritage property. The place has an amazing classic ambience. The food is not your regular cafe food. It's a gourmet style and perfect for fine dining. The multiple rooms with various seating options will certainly impress you. The decor is aptly done. The staff are all so hospitable. Absolutely loved my experience here and will be revisiting soon. Highly recommend!
Edit: Visited again for the second time. The rooftop seating was lovely! Their Pizza is a must try. Will be revisiting soon.

placeMetadata.name: National Library

sources.snippet: Located in Belvedere Estate, Kolkata is India‚Äôs largest library by volume and public record, spread across an area of 30 acres, National Library. Initially designed as a royal house, influenced by the English architectural style of the 19th century, it serves as a symbol of imperial power in India. Curved entryways lead to the majestic building designed with decorative galleries, overlooking the lush lawns.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to Visit in Kolkata for Travelling Architect

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The National Library is an impressive institution boasting a vast and remarkable assortment of books from all corners of India. As the largest library in the country, it's a haven for book enthusiasts and history aficionados alike. Housing over 2.2 million books, taking a leisurely stroll through its halls offers an opportunity to immerse oneself in the essence of ancient literature carefully preserved within its walls. The library also provides an awe-inspiring ambiance with ample space and an exceptional collection of books.
placeMetadata.address: Alipore, Kolkata, West Bengal 700027, India

reviews.reviewText: Fantastic ambience. Huge space. Awesome collection of Books. Very good maintenance of old building of British period. Apart from reading, one can feel the thrilling of witnessing the historical building that was once used as residence of Warren Hastings, the Governor General of Bengal during Colonial Rule.

It's a heritage place. Recently the old building has been revamped. Even staff is very helpful and speaks multiple Indian languages because of the diversity of the library staff. But simple staff like getting book or magazines photocopied is complicated, time consuming and very bureacratic. Magazines are supposed to be in an order but they weren't. Washrooms are clean but not the best maintained. Water coolers are just smash worthy as either they don't work or takes centuries to fill a one litre bottle.
National library is very beautiful and library environment are excellent are the guard and all stuff's behavior just awesome.

Calm, peaceful, historical place. Staffs are helpful. If you want to become a member you have to go there collect the membership form. Please take the documents with you as they are required to get the application form.
One can get many precious books, documents here. Right procedure has to be followed for the access of information.
Amazing collection of books.
Library with a great historical significance. Currently being renovated and temporarily shifted to adjacent Bhasha Bhavan
It's a nice place for reading lover. Great collection of documents.

placeMetadata.name: Maidan

sources.snippet: The landmark, iconic monuments are found in and around the Maidan and Hogg‚Äôs Market areas. Victoria Memorial, a white marble monument built between 1906 and 1921 to honor Queen Victoria‚Äôs memory following her death, is one such monument that should be on every traveller‚Äôs itinerary. Though it was designed by William Emerson, a British architect, there are Mughal, Venetian and Islamic architectural influences on the building as well, notable in its domes and Taj Mahal-like features.
sources.shortName: Exploring Kolkata‚Äôs Colonial Architecture

placeMetadata.description: Maidan is a massive green space with trails, riverside picnic spots, and sporting venues that include the iconic Eden Gardens cricket ground, golf courses, and a polo club. Set in stately landscaped gardens, Victoria Memorial is a white-domed museum displaying Indian and Western art. St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral is a neo-Gothic landmark from 1847. Family attractions include Nehru Children‚Äôs Museum and M.P. Birla Planetarium.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Maidan is a sprawling green space in the heart of Kolkata, offering trails, picnic spots by the riverside, and various sporting venues including the famous Eden Gardens cricket ground. The area also features Victoria Memorial, a museum showcasing Indian and Western art, as well as St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral. Families can enjoy attractions like Nehru Children‚Äôs Museum and M.P. Birla Planetarium nearby.
placeMetadata.address: New Market Area, Kolkata, West Bengal, India

ops.insert: Elegant, domed, white marble museum, opened in 1921, housing displays on the history of Kolkata.
Landmark Anglican church completed in 1847, with restored steeple and notable stained glass windows.
Bustling cantilever road bridge opened since 1943 and spanning the Hooghly River.
Indian heritage museum with sections on archaeology, art, anthropology and geology, founded in 1814.
Stately, 19th-century private residence with unique art & landscaped grounds, plus guided tours.
British East India Company headquarters designed in 1777, now West Bengal state government offices.
Neo-Gothic 1862 building housing India's oldest high court, designed after a Belgian statehouse.
Built in 1813, this Roman Doric-style government structure houses a local-history museum.
Ancestral home of the historic Tagore family, now a museum spotlighting its members‚Äô lives.
9 ornate spires top this riverside red and cream 1800s temple, with shrines to Krishna and Vishnu.
Set in a grand 18th-century palace, the country's largest library is home to over 2.2 million books.
This sprawling, 18th-century Christian graveyard features large, picturesque tombstones.
Neoclassical structure with a high white dome built in the 1860s on the site of a British fort.

place.name: Raja Ram Mohan Roy Memorial Museum

ops.insert: Colonial-era residence of 1800s socio-religious reformer Rammohan Roy, with exhibits about his life.

Kolkata (formerly Calcutta) is the capital of India's West Bengal state. Founded as an East India Company trading post, it was India's capital under the British Raj from 1773‚Äì1911. Today it‚Äôs known for its grand colonial architecture, art galleries and cultural festivals. It‚Äôs also home to Mother House, headquarters of the Missionaries of Charity, founded by Mother Teresa, whose tomb is on site.
Open since 1927, this stylish tearoom serves Indian & European cakes/pastries, plus light fare.

place.name: Girish Ch. Dey & Nakur Ch. Nandy

ops.insert: Enduring counter-serve offering traditional Indian confections such as sandesh since 1844.

Maidan is a massive green space with trails, riverside picnic spots, and sporting venues that include the iconic Eden Gardens cricket ground, golf courses, and a polo club. Set in stately landscaped gardens, Victoria Memorial is a white-domed museum displaying Indian and Western art. St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral is a neo-Gothic landmark from 1847. Family attractions include Nehru Children‚Äôs Museum and M.P. Birla Planetarium.
British colonial monument rededicated in 1969 to martyrs who fought for Indian independence.

Popularly known as Dalhousie Square, administrative district BBD Bagh has old-world charm. Grand, colonial-era landmarks include the Town Hall, the Writers‚Äô Building, and iconic Eden Gardens, one of the world‚Äôs largest cricket grounds. Sunset views across the Hooghly River and theme park rides are among the attractions at Millennium Park. Mullick Ghat Flower Market has baskets filled with vivid blooms and garlands.

place.name: Ramakrishna Mission Swami Vivekananda's Ancestral House and Cultural Centre

ops.insert: Multidisciplinary space with bright galleries displaying work by local artists, plus a theater.
This rustic-chic cafe in a stylish artisans' shop offers light bites, espresso drinks & patio seats.
A grand residential building with a historical museum & a large courtyard used for Hindu festivals.
Charming shop specializing in saris & traditional clothing, textiles, handmade jewelry & crafts.
Quaint movie theater in an 1883 building with concessions & occasional live plays.
Neoclassical estate built in 1835 & exhibiting varied art, open with permit gotten in advance.
This Chinese temple set in a 1924 Colonial-style building features a shrine to a god of war.

Bhowanipore is a residential district known for Netaji Bhawan, the former home of Indian nationalist Nataji Bose, now a museum with memorabilia, including a car used in his escape from house arrest. Grand, colonial edifices Nizam Palace and the Calcutta Club occupy busy Acharya Jagadish Chandra Bose Road, also home to high-end hotels. Nearby is the huge, Raj-era Victoria Memorial museum, surrounded by formal gardens.
Howrah is a city in the Indian state of West Bengal. Howrah is located on the western bank of the Hooghly River, opposite to its twin city of Kolkata. Wikipedia.
New Alipore is an upscale and standard locality of South Kolkata in Kolkata district in the Indian state of West Bengal. Wikipedia.

New Town is a planned Satellite city of Kolkata in the Indian state of West Bengal. It is administered by NKDA. New Town is declared as a "Solar City" and "Smart Green City" by Government of India. Wikipedia.

Joka is a locality in South 24 Parganas district of West Bengal, India. It is a part of greater Behala region. This place is mostly known for Indian Institute of Management Calcutta and ESIC Medical College and Hospital. Wikipedia.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb: Kolkata, a city steeped in history and culture, is a treasure trove of architectural marvels that tell the story of its rich past. From the grand Victoria Memorial, a stunning tribute to Queen Victoria, to the intricate designs of the Marble Palace, each structure reflects the city's unique blend of colonial influence and local artistry. As you stroll through the bustling streets, you'll encounter iconic landmarks like the Howrah Bridge, which gracefully spans the Hooghly River, and the majestic St. Paul's Cathedral, showcasing the city's Gothic charm. The Wanderlog team is passionate about uncovering the hidden gems and celebrated institutions that make Kolkata's architecture so captivating. Whether you're admiring the neoclassical elegance of the Writers' Building or exploring the historic Jorasanko Thakurbari, the ancestral home of Rabindranath Tagore, there's a story waiting to be discovered at every corner. So, lace up your walking shoes and get ready to explore the architectural wonders that define this vibrant city!

data.title: The 50 most romantic places in Kolkata (Calcutta)

placeMetadata.name: Victoria Memorial

sources.snippet: Commissioned by Lord Curzon, the then Viceroy of India, this vast white marble palace was designed to commemorate Queen Victoria‚Äôs demise in 1901. While the main highlights of the inside are the soaring central chamber and the Calcutta Gallery, an excellent, even-handed exhibition tracing the city‚Äôs colonial-era history, the outside renders magnificently photogenic views across reflecting ponds from the northeast and northwest along with a large, well-tended park. You can set the park and outside lawn as your photo-shoot spot with the magnificent piece of white marble as the backdrop.
sources.shortName: 7 Stunning Places in Kolkata for a Romantic Photoshoot

sources.snippet: This historic marble building was constructed in the early 1900's in the memory of the Late Queen Victoria. Build across several hundred acres, the Victoria memorial was beautified by big ponds and beautiful gardens. Inside the memorial is a museum, which stores several beautiful artifacts from Kolkata's golden past since the time of its creation by Job Charnock, detailed portraits of Queen Elizabeth and Prince Albert lifestyles, their dresses, and other artifacts.
sources.shortName: 15 Romantic places in Kolkata perfect for a date with your girlfriend

sources.snippet: Victoria Memorial- has a striking resemblance to the Taj Mahal, is the ultimate destination for couples who spend some quality time and embrace some architectural splendor at the same time, and is dedicated to Queen Victoria of England. Inside it has 25 galleries and the marvelous Indo-Saracenic revivalist style of architecture is also commendable. The structure is surrounded by lush green shrubs and gardens, water bodies, and colorful flowers.
sources.shortName: 31 Best Romantic Places in Kolkata for Couples [2023]

sources.snippet: The Victoria Memorial is excellent for those yearning for a locale embodying love and history. This splendid edifice, crafted from alabaster, is a poignant tribute to Queen Victoria and an enduring testament to the profound affection shared between a sovereign and her subjects. A sojourn within its opulent gardens and stately architecture is a journey back in time, making it the perfect place to visit in Kolkata for couples.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Romantic Places to Visit in Kolkata for Couples

sources.snippet: The Victoria Memorial was built in 1916 in memory of Queen Victoria, who was Empress of India from 1876 to 1901. It is a fine piece of British architecture in the heart of Kolkata, a city bursting with colors, energy, and culture. The Victoria Memorial building houses an impressive collection of historical artifacts and is a great place to visit on the 21st-century heritage trail of India.
sources.shortName: 17 Best Places For Couples In Kolkata: Romantic Places

sources.snippet: Located in the heart of Kolkata, the Victoria Memorial is a beautiful white monument ‚Äì a palace in structure ‚Äì built in memory of Queen Victoria. It also located near to 64 acres of garden, which makes it one of the symbols of the British architectural style. It has now become a museum and currently has 25 galleries adorned with portraits, sculptures, paintings and historical relics.
sources.shortName: Best sightseeing places in Kolkata for Couples

sources.snippet: One of the primary tourist places in Kolkata, the Victoria Memorial is a place the mysticism of which cannot simply be put in words. Accompanied with lush green gardens and quaint water bodies, this monument in sheer marble does remind you quite a bit of the symbol of love, Taj Mahal, thus making it one of the best places in Kolkata for couples. Also Read : Monuments in Kolkata
sources.shortName: 23 Places To Visit In Kolkata For Couples, Places For Couples In Kolkata

sources.snippet: Victoria Memorial Hall is one of the major tourist attractions in Kolkata. This lush green garden and bright marble monument mixed with strange water bodies reminds you of the Taj Mahal, the symbol of love, so it is one of the best places for couples. Don‚Äôt forget to capture some moments even with nice scenes or structures in the background for the Insta-Story, Facebook-Story.
sources.shortName: Best Romantic Places in Kolkata ‚Äî City of joy, Kolkata | by Atanu Ghosh

sources.snippet: Scattered in an area of approximately 56 acres, the place is a must visit for all the tourists coming to Kolkata. It houses nearly 22 well-manicured gardens, around 3,800 paintings of diverse artists and 28,394 artefacts. Queen Victoria‚Äôs statue is placed within the memorial and the architecture of museum inside is simply marvellous.
sources.shortName: Best 18 Places To Visit In Kolkata (2024 Updated List)

sources.snippet: A testament to the colonial history of Kolkata, this beautiful marble hall is dedicated to the memory of Queen Victoria. Its design echoes that of the Taj Mahal as does its beauty. Perched atop the central dome of the Memorial is an angel figure - The Angel of Victory as well as other allegorical sculptures.
sources.shortName: 27 Romantic Places in Kolkata For Couples in 2024

sources.snippet: When talking about romantic spots in Kolkata, the first name that comes in mind is The Victoria Memorial. Victoria Memorial, a historic building built in honor of Queen Victoria, is the pride of Kolkata. This extraordinary architecture made of white marble is one of the most romantic places in Kolkata.

placeMetadata.description: Elegant, domed, white marble museum, opened in 1921, housing displays on the history of Kolkata.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Victoria Memorial is an exquisite white marble museum in Kolkata, built in 1921 as a tribute to Queen Victoria. The grand architecture and well-maintained gardens make it a popular spot for locals and tourists alike. Inside, the museum showcases the history of Kolkata and the British Empire in India. It also boasts a remarkable collection of over 5,000 paintings by renowned artists from the Bengal School of Art.
placeMetadata.address: Victoria Memorial Hall, 1, Queens Way, Maidan, Kolkata, West Bengal 700071, India

Such a marvellous architecture.
A must visit place in Kolkata.
Food & water is not allowed inside the Memorial.
The place is very neat & clean & the information is placed for all the monuments.
This place can be crowded during weekends.
The park outside is amazing during sunset time.
History lover will love this place.
Place has some entry fees also..
If you want save some fare you can come by bus also..

Visited on 10th April couldn‚Äôt upload at that time, so reviewing now...

1. The monument is stunning, showcasing colonial era architecture blended beautifully with Indian craftsmanship.
2.The gardens are lush, green and very well maintained, perfect for a peaceful stroll.

The Victoria Memorial is one of the most beautiful and grand monuments I‚Äôve visited. The white marble architecture looks stunning, especially during sunrise or sunset when the light hits the domes. The vast gardens around it are well-maintained and perfect for a peaceful walk or to sit and relax.

Inside, the museum offers a fascinating glimpse into colonial history, with impressive paintings, artifacts, and sculptures. The collection is quite large, so it‚Äôs worth taking your time to explore each gallery.

Do plan to spend at least 2‚Äì3 hours here to fully enjoy both the museum and the surrounding gardens. There‚Äôs also a light and sound show in the evening that brings the history of the memorial to life.

Overall, a must-visit place in Kolkata that combines history, architecture, and nature beautifully!

Nice memorial to visit with kids. Neat and clean. The place needs more information guide for visitors. Only one gate is functional. Water bottles not allowed inside. That‚Äôs weird. Overall it‚Äôs a good place to spend some time.

One of the if not the most iconic landmarks of Kolkata. It is a hard to miss place.
The museum itself is closed on Monday but the gardens are open. So it is nice to visit the place.
They have an entry fee for the garden and a different entry fee for the museum.
The gardens are nice to stroll and soak in the greenery.
They have a small pond as well.
It is good patch of green right in middle of the city.
They have good connections via local bus and metro.
The metro is about 400-500 meters away.
They have plenty of shops outside the gate.
They also have strict policy of foodstuffs being allowed into the museum area.
The gardens have a restroom as well.
Plan to have a good walk and so have good shoes and also carry umbrella as if it rains then it‚Äôs bad and if it‚Äôs too sunny as well it gets bad.

It offers a wide range of recreational activities such as boating, cycling, and a playground for children. The park features various attractions including wildflower meadows, restaurants, lakes, grassland, an urban museum, craft shops, gardens, an amphitheater and more. Visitors can enjoy the serene natural surroundings and take part in activities like dual cycling and boat rides.

reviews.reviewText:
Wow, Eco Park in Kolkata is such a gem! üåø Tucked away in New Town, this massive 480-acre park is my go-to for a fun, chill day out. It‚Äôs got everything‚Äîgorgeous lakes, vibrant gardens, and even mini Seven Wonders to snap pics with (just INR 30 to see ‚Äòem)! üö§ Boating‚Äôs a blast (INR 50‚Äì300), and I love renting a cycle (INR 70‚Äì150) to zip around. The musical fountain at night? Total magic! üåü

It‚Äôs super family-friendly, though I wish there were more kid facilities. Everyone from toddlers to grandparents can enjoy it, but it‚Äôs not the best for wheelchairs. The park‚Äôs pretty eco-conscious with solar lights and recycling, but those plastic food stall cups bug me. ‚ôªÔ∏è Entry‚Äôs only INR 30 (kids INR 15), and most activities are dirt cheap. Go early to dodge the weekend crowds! Pack water, sunscreen, and maybe a picnic‚ÄîEco Park‚Äôs perfect for making memories! üòÑ

As the sun begins to dip behind the treetops, Rabindra Sarovar transforms into something magical. The golden light reflects off the still waters of the lake, painting the entire scene in warm hues of orange and pink. Birds return to their nests, their silhouettes dancing across the sky, while some glide just above the water, creating ripples in the calm surface.

Families stroll along the tree-lined paths, some laughing, some simply soaking in the quiet. Children play near the benches, and couples find quiet corners to sit and talk. Occasionally, you‚Äôll spot kayakers gently paddling across the lake, their boats cutting through the sunset‚Äôs reflection like brushstrokes on a canvas.

It‚Äôs not just a park‚Äîit‚Äôs a breath of fresh air, a reminder of how beautiful moments can still exist in the heart of a busy city. Whether you‚Äôre here for a peaceful walk, to take photos, or to simply sit and watch nature do its thing, evenings at Rabindra Sarovar offer a rare kind of calm that stays with you long after you leave.

A serene place in the lap of nature. Place for walk around, relaxation and for spending one's leisure time amongst the vast lake, eye soothing trees, birds and breeze. Well maintained.

This is one of my favourite parts of Kolkata. It's a paradise for nature lovers. It's far from the city's pollution and noise. There is so much greens and peace here.

Visited Millennium Park in Howrah and had a great experience, especially with the boat ride, which was the highlight of the visit. The ride was smooth and enjoyable, and the ticket price was incredibly affordable‚Äîjust Rs. 6 for a one-way trip, making it a great value for money.

The park itself is a nice place to relax by the river, but the atmosphere was quite humid, which made it a bit uncomfortable to stay for long, especially during the day. Despite that, it's a good spot for a quick outing, and the boat ride alone makes it worth visiting.

It is a wonderful location for an afternoon stroll. While there was an initial entry fee of ‚Çπ20, access to parks 2 and 3 is now completely FREE. Park 1, however, is reserved for official visits. Furthermore, all the rides have been temporarily removed. Although the amphitheater is often utilized by roller skaters, it remains available for various artistic performances. Overall, it is a delightful place to relax and uplift one's spirits.

Millennium Park is a peaceful and scenic spot perfect for a relaxing walk by the riverside. The view of the Ganges, especially during evening, is absolutely stunning. It‚Äôs clean, well-maintained, and has plenty of seating areas to just sit and enjoy nature. The palm trees and soft lighting in the evening create a beautiful ambiance. Great place for photography too.

Millennium Park is a beautiful riverside park that offers a peaceful escape in the middle of the city. The walking paths are clean and lined with palm trees, making it ideal for morning or evening strolls. The view of the river is absolutely stunning, especially under a bright blue sky. A perfect place for families, couples, or anyone looking for a calm and scenic spot.

Millenium Park is a go-to place for the people living in Kolkata. The park boasts well-landscaped gardens, clean walkways lined with palm trees, and plenty of benches from which you can admire stunning views of the Howrah and Vidyasagar bridges especially beautiful at sunset.

However, the park is not well maintained at all. Uncleanliness is evident everywhere within the park.

We went for a electric water metro ride- Dheu however all the tickets were sold. As I believe, one door closes yet opens uo another one. We explored the Millennium Park. It was a rainy afternoon. The park was empty offering a lush green view. Most of the rides which were once an eye-catcher were dilapidated and counting on their last days. The shabby ticket counter called upon us to remind of its golden busy days. Broken things although looks sad has their own way of showing beauty, that it is okay to let go and hold onto the memories buried in the crevices. The trees were happy though, the leaves getting to dance upon the drizzle. We had a good time with everything.

Millennium Park located at Strand Road, Kolkata, on the banks of the Hooghly River. The park is 2.5km long and lies on Hooghly‚Äôs eastern shore opposite to the Railway Club and near the Fairlie Ghat. You can easily view the¬†Howrah Bridge¬†from the park. The park is located in the BBD Bagh area of Kolkata, near the¬†General Post Office¬†and the Calcutta High Court.
The park has been beautified with a variety of trees and lots of pretty lights. The view of the Hooghly waterfront and the Howrah Bridge from the park makes Millennium Park worth a visit. A variety of activities at Millennium Park include:

Opening time- 10.00 AM- 6.30 PM/daily and entry fee- RS. 10.00.

Millennium Park ‚Äì Where the Sun Whispers Goodbye in the City‚Äôs Glow

Millennium Park isn‚Äôt just a place‚Äîit‚Äôs a feeling. As the sun begins to dip, the park blushes in gold. Trees glow, the Hooghly shimmers, and the city gently slows its pace. In these golden hours, the park unveils its quiet magic.

The air turns softer, laughter warmer, and even silence feels romantic. Couples find cozy corners, steps grow slower, and hearts sync with the sunset. With the majestic river flowing beside and Howrah Bridge bathed in amber light, it‚Äôs a moment that belongs in poetry.

Perfectly couple-friendly, the park offers breezy walkways, inviting benches, and peaceful views made for long conversations. That view of the setting sun behind the bridge? Pure magic.

Whether you‚Äôre walking hand in hand, watching the sky change, or just soaking it all in‚ÄîMillennium Park at golden hour is Kolkata‚Äôs softest love story.A must-visit for romantic souls and golden-hour chasers.

reviews.reviewText:
üåüüåüüåüüåüüåü (5/5)

A Slice of Peace in the Heart of Kolkata

Princep Ghat is truly one of Kolkata's most iconic and peaceful spots. The view of the Hooghly River, especially during sunset, is breathtaking. Whether you're on a casual walk, enjoying a boat ride, or simply sitting by the riverside, the atmosphere is calm and refreshing. The white Palladian-style monument is beautifully maintained and adds a historical charm.

Evenings are vibrant with street food vendors, local musicians, and couples strolling hand in hand. It's a perfect blend of nature, history, and local life. The surrounding gardens are clean, and the nearby railway station makes it easily accessible.

Highly recommend visiting if you're in Kolkata ‚Äî don‚Äôt forget your camera, the views are picture-perfect!
Good place to visit for a boat ride in evenings for sunsets. You can also walk here in the garden areas and enjoy the scenic view of river Ganga.

Princep Ghat is one of Kolkata‚Äôs most iconic landmarks and a must-visit destination for both locals and tourists. Located along the banks of the Hooghly River, it beautifully combines history, architecture, and natural beauty. Built in 1843 in memory of the British scholar James Prinsep, the structure boasts stunning colonial-style design and is surrounded by lush green gardens, making it an ideal spot for relaxation and photography. The place is especially charming during the evenings when the Vidyasagar Setu, which looms majestically overhead, is lit up, creating a magical atmosphere.

Visitors can enjoy peaceful walks along the riverbank, take a boat ride for a mesmerizing view of the sunset, or simply sit and watch the gentle flow of the Hooghly. Street food stalls nearby offer delicious local snacks, adding to the experience. It‚Äôs also a favorite spot for couples, families, and photographers due to its scenic charm. The area is well-maintained, with clean surroundings and proper seating arrangements.

Reaching Princep Ghat is easy, as it is well-connected by road and even has a nearby railway station. Early mornings and evenings are the best times to visit, as you can witness the golden hues of sunrise or sunset reflecting on the water. Whether you‚Äôre looking for a peaceful escape, a place to unwind, or a spot to soak in Kolkata‚Äôs heritage, Princep Ghat offers it all. Highly recommended for a serene and memorable experience in the city.

History:
Princep Ghat is a ghat built in 1841 during the British period on the banks of the Hooghly River in Kolkata, India. The Palladian porch was designed by W. Fitzgerald and built in 1843 in memory of the eminent Anglo-Indian scholar and antiquarian James Prinsep.

Note for tourists :
Princep Ghat and its surroundings are really beautiful. Especially the view of Vidyasagar Bridge from this ghat adds extra charm. This place is also considered as a shooting spot. This place is a great place for couples.
You can enjoy a comfortable boat ride at Princep Ghat in Kolkata. If you are a couple or with friends or family, you can rent an entire boat for yourself. You need to fix the boat rent before riding.

I really enjoyed my visit to Princep Ghat.  There's a walkway that runs parallel to the Ganga ‚Äî perfect for a leisurely stroll, a heart-to-heart chat, or even just some quiet reflection with the breeze in your hair and the holy river beside you.

The ghats aren‚Äôt continuous so you can't differentiate them (math joke). In fact, the statement is entirely opposite in English. You can differentiate only when they are not continuous. Strange subjects!

Scattered along the way are small eateries and chai stalls, perfect for grabbing a snack or sipping a hot cup of tea while watching the the river at the end of its more than 2k km journey.

One of the best places to go to see the natural beauty and scenery of this place is mesmerizing. You can spend some time on the bank of Hoogly river and take a boat ride. The best go beyond the hustle and bustle of the city. There is too much greenery and many food stalls here that serve much delicious food .

This location, which is on the banks of the River Hoogli, has a beautiful park and boating facilities.James Princep is commemorated by a monument.A very excellent spot for evening leisure. There are food stands there. The setting sun is stunning.
The Ganges-banks and Princep Ghat have been improved and made more beautiful during the current regime. Previously haunted by criminals, these locations are now a safe and lovely place to take an evening stroll, a refreshing dip, or to perform rituals in an orderly and respectful manner.

Princep Ghat is a serene and picturesque destination that is perfect for a relaxing boat ride with stunning views of the sunset. An oasis in the heart of Kolkata‚ÄîElliot Park is where the city slows down and breathes.

Tucked just behind Tata Centre and a 2-minute stroll from Maidan Metro Station, Elliot Park is one of those rare green pockets that balances urban buzz with serene calm. Whether you‚Äôre escaping office stress, walking off a heavy lunch from Park Street, or just craving silence in the city‚Äîthis place delivers.

Why Elliot Park stands out üåø

1. Immaculately maintained: The walking tracks are clean, the lawns are manicured, and the benches are never too crowded. A welcome surprise, especially in central Kolkata!

2. Perfect for walkers and joggers: The circular path is wide, shaded, and ideal for early morning jogs or evening strolls. You‚Äôll find fitness enthusiasts, seniors, and college students all vibing in harmony.

3. Green escape with skyline views: While you enjoy the chirping birds and tall trees, the distant silhouette of downtown Kolkata peeks through‚Äîbest of both worlds.

4. Safe and peaceful: Entry is free but secure. It feels family-friendly, with couples, kids, and elderly visitors all coexisting without any nuisance.

Extras that make it special:

Photography alert: Visit around 4:30‚Äì5:30 PM for golden light filtering through the trees‚Äîideal for portraits or casual reels.

Proximity bonus: Maidan Metro, Victoria Memorial, and St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral are all within walking distance. Makes for a beautiful half-day circuit.

No hawkers inside = clean experience. But don‚Äôt worry‚Äîthere‚Äôs always a bhel puri or tea stall right outside the gates when hunger hits.

Heads-up ‚ö†Ô∏è

Closed on Mondays for maintenance.

No food or loud music allowed‚Äîthis is a calm space, not a picnic ground.

Limited shaded seating‚Äîcarry a cap if you're visiting in the afternoon.

Local tip: Carry a book or some headphones and let the world slow down. If you‚Äôre a working professional, this is your go-to spot for a reset. If you‚Äôre a tourist, it‚Äôs the quiet pause you didn‚Äôt know you needed between Victoria and Park Street.

Elliot Park is proof that in the middle of chaos, Kolkata still has places that let you just... be.

If this review helped you find your new favorite spot, tap that üëç Helpful button and show some love for the city's green lungs!

Nicco Park is without a doubt one of the best attractions in Kolkata for a fun-filled day with family and friends. From the moment you step inside, you‚Äôre greeted with a lively atmosphere, lush greenery, and well-organized pathways that make the entire park easy to explore. It truly lives up to its nickname ‚Äî the "Disneyland of the East."

The variety of rides here is impressive. Whether you‚Äôre an adventure seeker who loves high-speed roller coasters and the Cyclone ride, or someone who prefers calmer experiences like the cable car or toy train, there‚Äôs something for everyone. The park maintains high safety standards, and you can see staff actively ensuring that rides are operated smoothly and securely.

The Water Park section is a highlight in itself ‚Äî perfect for cooling off on a warm day. The wave pool, water slides, and lazy river are all well-maintained and super fun. Kids absolutely love the splash zones, and adults can enjoy the slides just as much.

Another great thing about Nicco Park is the cleanliness. You‚Äôll find dustbins at regular intervals, and the staff are quick to keep the area neat. There are also plenty of food stalls offering everything from snacks to full meals, with both local and international options. The prices are reasonable for the quality and convenience.

It‚Äôs not just about rides ‚Äî Nicco Park also has beautiful gardens, a small aquarium, and various fun activities that make it more than just an amusement park. You can easily spend an entire day here without feeling bored.

Overall, Nicco Park offers excellent value for money and delivers an experience that‚Äôs enjoyable for people of all ages. It‚Äôs a must-visit in Kolkata if you‚Äôre looking for adventure, entertainment, and a bit of nostalgia all in one place.

Nicco Park is a great place for a fun-filled day with family and friends. It offers a wide variety of rides and attractions, especially for kids and young adults. The main amusement park has some exciting rides and scenic spots, and the water park is definitely a highlight, especially during the summer.

However, it can get very crowded on weekends, especially in the water park section. Be prepared for long queues for most of the popular rides. If you're planning a visit, weekdays might be a better option for a more relaxed experience.

Overall, Nicco Park offers a memorable day out, especially for families, but planning ahead and visiting on a less busy day can make a big difference.

Nicco Park is by far the best amusement park in Kolkata. I‚Äôve visited countless places in the city, but none have given me such consistent joy throughout the entire day. reviews.reviewText:
The Indian Museum is a must-visit destination for history lovers and culture enthusiasts. It houses an incredible collection of artifacts from ancient times, including sculptures, fossils, coins, textiles, and more. The Egyptian mummy and the grand Buddhist galleries are particularly fascinating.

The museum is quite large, so give yourself at least 2‚Äì3 hours to explore it properly. It can get a little warm inside during summer months, so I recommend visiting in winter for a more comfortable experience. Overall, it's an enriching and educational experience that offers a glimpse into India‚Äôs vast and diverse heritage.

I love exploring museums and have visited museums across all major Indian cities, and I can say with confidence that this is the finest museum in India, at least from my experience. The collection is vast and incredibly diverse, showcasing historic items and antiques from across time and geography. The star attraction is the 4000 year old Egyptian mummy in the Egypt Gallery, which is truly fascinating. Apart from that, the museum also houses remarkable Buddhist archaeological treasures from Gandhara (present-day Kandahar, Afghanistan), along with fascinating galleries on fossils, zoology, birds, geology and what not. The Botany Survey of India is also part of this museum, adding to its richness and diversity. I would recommend keeping at least 2‚Äì3 hours aside to explore properly. This museum is a journey through both history and culture, and an absolute must visit.

Visiting the Indian Museum was an enlightening and enjoyable experience!

Every gallery tells a unique story, and I learned so much, especially in the Zoological and Egyptian sections, which were my favorites‚Äîtruly captivating!

The museum is a paradise for history buffs and curious travelers, offering a deep dive into India‚Äôs rich heritage and beyond.

The museum is conveniently located near Park Street Metro, making it super accessible.

However, the ticket prices are a bit steep for college students, and there are extra charges for mobile phone photography.

The cafeteria prices, though, are quite reasonable.

I highly recommend taking your time to explore this inspiring and educational gem.

Had a great time with my buddies!

It‚Äôs a journey through time that‚Äôs well worth taking, imperfections and all.

I just amazed by seeing this type of collection. First I checked painting and then the real things the bones of the animals. It really feels like my ticket is worth of it.

I truly suggest to visit it.

Founded in 1814 at the cradle of the Asiatic Society of Bengal (at the present building of the Asiatic Society, 1 Park Street, Kolkata), Indian Museum is the earliest and the largest multipurpose Museum not only in the Indian subcontinent but also in the Asia-Pacific region of the world.

I visited the Indian Museum on 23rd August 2022, and it was my very first time exploring this historic treasure-and truly, it was an amazing experience.

From ancient artifacts to rare sculptures, fossils, and cultural exhibits, every section of the museum tells a fascinating story. Walking through its grand halls felt like stepping into a time machine-rich with history, knowledge, and artistic beauty. I was deeply impressed by the vast collection and the way everything was preserved and presented.

As someone with a love for history and culture, this visit was both inspiring and educational. I captured some memorable photos during my tour, but the real magic is something you have to experience in person.

If you‚Äôre ever in Kolkata, a visit to the Indian Museum is an absolute must. Whether you‚Äôre a curious traveler or a history enthusiast, you‚Äôll leave with a deeper appreciation of South Asia‚Äôs rich heritage.

The magnificent stone work would left the viewer speechless. No need to buy tickets in advance and  interestingly buying a photography ticket one can get permission of taking photos almost all the things though rate is different for mobile camera and digital cameras.

The Indian Museum, Kolkata, is a true treasure and a must-visit for anyone who loves history, art, and culture. Being the oldest and largest museum in India‚Äîand even in Asia‚Äîit offers a fascinating journey through time. From rare fossils, ancient coins, and archaeological wonders to stunning paintings, stuffed animals, skeletons, and even an Egyptian mummy, every section has something to amaze you.

It‚Äôs not just for history lovers‚Äîkids will find it fun and educational too. The location is excellent, with easy connectivity via metro and buses. Tickets are reasonably priced, and you‚Äôll find helpful facilities like a baggage counter, clean toilets, and a cafeteria.

A tip: banned items such as matches, cigarettes, and gutkha are not allowed, so leave them at home. Mobile photography is allowed if you purchase a photography pass.

If you want to enjoy the full experience, set aside at least 3‚Äì4 hours‚Äîyou‚Äôll leave with memories and knowledge that will stay with you forever!

The museum has an impressive collection and a lot of interesting exhibits, especially if you‚Äôre into history and archaeology.
Most of all I liked miniature paintings collection on the second floor.
However, it‚Äôs very hot inside ‚Äî they don‚Äôt use air conditioning, so be prepared if you‚Äôre visiting during warmer months. Worth a visit, but could be more comfortable.

reviews.reviewText: Around 18 of us decided to celebrate our class reunion at The Bridge. When I called up for reservations I was put in contact with Mr. Tabrez. He guided me with the menu and did all the needful. We went for a la carte. The kamikaze shots were really good. We also had koliwada prawns,  fish fingers, chicken lasuni tikka and hara bhara kabab as starters . The pizza and kulfi falooda was also good. The experience was very good. We had a gala time.

Had a morning breakfast with family on Father‚Äôs Day, Sunday. The ambience and service is excellent. Wide choice of food. Particularly liked the well made carrot & beetroot juice. The clear soup was soothing. Made my own salad from the ingredients! Overall, a pleasant experience.

Had ordered their Chicken Stroganoff, Pork Chops, Beef Steak along with drinks. The Beef steak though was requested well done, came out medium rare. The chef went back in and prepared another one which was then cooked right but the portion was reduced. The Stroganoff was not too great either and the portion served was horribly small. The pork chops were dry. Very disappointed with the food. Food is not worth the money. The ambience is good though and the table service too.

I stayed at The Park Hotel on Park Street for four nights and had the pleasure of enjoying breakfast every day at The Bridge restaurant. The spread is excellent‚Äîdelicious omelets, perfectly made French toast, fresh cakes, crunchy granola, flavorful dosa, and even puchka! Everything about the experience feels just right. The live counters offer great variety and the chefs do a fantastic job delivering taste and presentation.

What really sets the experience apart is the service‚ÄîMehak and her team are attentive and warm, creating a welcoming environment each morning. Special mention to Purtha, who is always on the move and has a sharp eye for customer needs.

The attention to detail from the entire staff is commendable.

The Bridge has become a favorite and I‚Äôll definitely be returning again and again.

Highly recommended for anyone visiting Kolkata.

At 1:10 served welcome drink, and asked what we want to take as starter; Veg/Non veg. They have not cleared the starter menu options. Every time asked for the next. The waste plate clear after the calling. All staff are moving here are there showing artificial business.

Taste: Only few items are maintaing the quality, most of other below average.
My opinion: This kind of Food options and pathetic service never deserve a 5 star catagory tag. Just waste of money and valuable time.

reviews.reviewText:
One of the most iconic landmarks of India!
Howrah Bridge is not just a bridge ‚Äî it‚Äôs a symbol of Kolkata‚Äôs vibrant culture and daily life. The view of the Hooghly River from here is breathtaking, especially during sunrise or sunset. You‚Äôll see thousands of people crossing it every day ‚Äî from local vendors to daily commuters.

It‚Äôs a perfect blend of engineering marvel and historic charm. A must-visit if you're in Kolkata!

üïô Best time to visit: Early morning or evening
üìçPro tip: Walk across the bridge for a real feel of Kolkata's heartbeat

The bridge is a landmark, and it looks absolutely majestic.

A bridge of this size to standing still without any support pillars makes it an engineering marvel.

I just wish it was cleaner. But Kolkata as a city is very dirty itself, so it's not really fair to expect that the bridge will be an exception.
An iconic landmark of Kolkata, Howrah Bridge is a stunning example of engineering and history. Best experienced at sunrise or night when it‚Äôs beautifully lit. A must-see symbol of the city.

The Howrah Bridge, officially known as Rabindra Setu, is not just a bridge‚Äîit is a living icon of Kolkata and one of the most remarkable engineering marvels of India. Standing proudly over the Hooghly River, this cantilever bridge connects the city of Howrah with the heart of Kolkata, carrying millions of people every single day.

What makes the Howrah Bridge truly fascinating is its sheer scale and design. Built without a single nut or bolt, it is held together entirely by rivets, a testament to the brilliance of early 20th-century engineering. Walking or driving across it, you can feel the pulse of the city‚Äîthe endless flow of buses, yellow taxis, rickshaws, and pedestrians all weaving into the daily rhythm of Kolkata life.

Beyond its practical importance, the bridge has immense cultural and emotional value. For many Bengalis, the first glimpse of the Howrah Bridge while entering Kolkata symbolizes ‚Äúhomecoming.‚Äù At night, when the bridge lights up and reflects on the waters of the Hooghly, it transforms into a breathtaking sight‚Äîone that photographers and travelers cherish.

The Howrah Bridge is more than just steel and structure; it is a silent witness to Kolkata‚Äôs history, from the days of British India to modern times. It has seen generations grow, countless stories unfold, and remains one of the busiest bridges in the world.

If you are visiting Kolkata, experiencing the Howrah Bridge‚Äîwhether by walking across it, viewing it from the ghats, or taking a ferry ride underneath‚Äîis an absolute must. It is not only an engineering wonder but also the very soul of the city.

Howrah Bridge is an iconic symbol of Kolkata and a must-visit attraction. This massive steel cantilever bridge spans the Hooghly River, connecting Kolkata and Howrah. Visitors love walking across it to experience the lively local life, colorful vendors, and stunning views of the river and city, especially at sunrise or sunset. Though often crowded, the bustling energy and historic charm make it a memorable part of any Kolkata visit. At night, it looks breathtakingly beautiful when lit up. The bridge is also known for its unique construction without nuts or bolts, held together by rivets. Overall, it‚Äôs a timeless landmark that perfectly captures Kolkata‚Äôs spirit.

üü¢What I likedüü¢
1. The bridge itself is solid and impressive ‚Äî built in 1943 using only rivets (no nuts/bolts), which is amazing even today.
2. The view of the Hooghly River from the bridge is beautiful during sunrise or sunset.
3. At night, the lights on the bridge give it a nice glow.
4. It connects the busy Howrah Railway Station with Kolkata city, so it's historically important.
5. For people interested in raw city life, walking across it feels like stepping into Kolkata‚Äôs real daily rhythm.

üî¥What I didn‚Äôt like (and others should know)üî¥

6. The surrounding area is one of the dirtiest I‚Äôve seen ‚Äî garbage, spit, urine ‚Äî it‚Äôs everywhere.
7. It‚Äôs overcrowded with honking traffic, vendors, and people rushing in every direction.
8. No one follows traffic rules, and there‚Äôs zero lane discipline.
9. Ola and taxi drivers around the area are known for overcharging, refusing to turn on the AC, and behaving rudely.
10. If you still want to go, visit early morning or late evening ‚Äî it's slightly better and less crowded then.

I personally loved this place, structure of this Bridge was absolutely astonishing. I went their in the evening, night view of this bridge was stunning. It's a perfect place for street photography, as a Bangladeshüáßüá© tourist i click lots good street photo this bridge. I recommended that you should go early to find some subject for photography.

It is such a great experience to see and travel on the bridge. It looks good in the morning and also in the night with the lights. The view from the bridge of the city is so good. There are so many people who travel on the bridge daily. The bridge is clean and neat. We need to see the bridge from the nearest ghat fornthe clear view of the whole bridge.

Coming to the food, we tried Chilli baby corn which was good, nothing extraordinary. Next was the Red Chilli fish, I loved this. The fish was really tender and the sauce was very tasty. We also tried the Chicken wings was was below average. Lastly, we had the Chilli Chicken in schezwan sauce, Chicken Hakka Noodles and Chicken Fried Rice. Noodles was amazing, realllyyyy good. The other two were quite basic. Also, they were out of Mocktails.

All mains and starters are prepared in the same sauce. So they basically taste similar. Overall it's good for the view, food isn't worth it.

Cafe ekante is quite a famous place to dine-in.
Let's get into the groove and discuss a bit.

It has two sections:
A Chinese special section that is on a house boat
And a Bengali food/ others in a restaurant. Both are quite adjacent to one another.

Also they have specific timings. Separate for evening snacks and dinner if u want to go for the Bengali food section. Starts from 7pm in eve. I think lunch is from 12-4 approx and in between it snacks.

Now for review:
Food : 3.5/5
Will not say it's super delicious. It's average. Fish items specially can improve a bit. As of chicken and mutton, I found it as per standard. I must suggest that you try their dov-chingri as it really caught the true blend of the dish.

Ambience: 5/5
Go on evening. That's one suggestion from me and I promise u won't regret. The whole setting is just mesmerising and beautiful if u go for a dinner. It can be romantic as well as family oriented too.

Service : 4/5
Service was good. There was this lad who really was very welcoming and timely. We ordered in intervals and took our time but they were patient and kept good behavior all throughout.

U can go visit but overall I found it very expensive. Not justified to pay so much for the dishes on the menu. U will be paying for the place more than the food and if that's okay with you, go ahead.

reviews.reviewText: Eden Gardens is the only Venue for International Cricket matches and IPL matches in Kolkata, West Bengal. It is always a treat to watch a Cricket match in Eden Gardens Cricket Stadium. It is managed by Cricket Association of Bengal( CAB). One of the ancient and nostalgic cricket stadiums in India. This stadium is famous for the enthusiasm of the Cricket Lovers and fans. The atmosphere is always electric as it remains forever...

Eden Gardens in Kolkata is a place every cricket fan dreams of visiting. Known as the ‚ÄúMecca of Indian cricket,‚Äù this iconic stadium can hold over 60,000 people, and the energy here is simply electrifying during a live match. The roar of the crowd, the sight of cricketing legends on the field, and the sheer scale of the arena make it unforgettable. Even if you are not a huge cricket follower, stepping inside gives you goosebumps because of its history and atmosphere. Outside the stadium, the Eden Gardens park offers a calm contrast, with shady trees and a small lake perfect for a quiet walk. A visit here blends passion, history, and the thrill of being part of something larger than life.

If cricket had a Heaven in India, then Eden Gardens would be it. This isn‚Äôt just a stadium ‚Äî it‚Äôs an emotion, a coliseum where legends are made, dreams are shattered, and 66,000+ voices chant in unison, shaking the very ground. Established in 1864, Eden Gardens is India‚Äôs oldest and second-largest cricket stadium, often called the ‚ÄúLords of the East‚Äù (but let‚Äôs be honest, even Lord‚Äôs can‚Äôt match the madness of an India-Pakistan match here!).
The roar of the crowd when Sourav Ganguly waved his shirt at Lord‚Äôs? That energy was born here. Sachin‚Äôs records, Dhoni‚Äôs helicopter shots, and Kolkata Knight Riders‚Äô IPL triumphs? All celebrated under Eden‚Äôs floodlights.
But Eden Gardens isn‚Äôt just about cricket. The Maidan surrounding it is Kolkata‚Äôs green lung, where footballers, morning walkers, and political rallies coexist in perfect chaos. Nearby, the Rabindra Sadan-Nandan cultural complex fuels Bengal‚Äôs love for theatre and films, while the Mohan Bagan, Mohammedan Sporting and East Bengal football clubs remind you that Kolkata‚Äôs second religion is football.
And then there‚Äôs the Eden Gardens Park, a serene escape with a picturesque lake, along with the pagoda, perfect for a quiet evening stroll (assuming you aren‚Äôt still hoarse from screaming at a match).
Verdict: Whether you love cricket or just the thrill of history, Eden Gardens is a must-visit.
Pro tip ‚Äî Catch a live match here; the energy is electric, and the crowd could out-cheer a rock concert!

Eden Gardens ‚Äì The Mecca of Indian Cricket!
Located in the Maidan area near BBD Bagh, right opposite the Calcutta High Court, this is a legendary venue that resonates deeply with the soul of cricket.

I have visited the stadium five times, and among those, the first-ever pink-ball Day-Night Test match between India and Bangladesh left a lasting impact on me. The stadium, with an approximate seating capacity of 68,000, was packed to the brim that day. During the event, I had a brief conversation with a ground staff member who shared info that the boundary dimensions are approximately 66‚Äì68 meters on the square side and 76‚Äì78 meters on the straight side.

The stands inside the stadium are named after cricketing legends such as Sourav Ganguly, Pankaj Roy, and Jagmohan Dalmiya. The B.C. Roy Club House named in honor of former West Bengal Chief Minister Dr. B.C. Roy.

While attending matches, you might experience cellular connectivity issues due to the presence of signal jammers. However, vendors selling water and snacks are quite efficient. There are also food corners and canteens inside the stadium offering decent food, albeit at higher-than-usual prices.

One area that consistently falls short is crowd management. In my experience, the gathering process lacks professionalism. A stadium of such iconic status should ideally have more streamlined crowd-control mechanisms.

For your information I want to let you know that Eden Gardens is owned by the Eastern Command of the Indian Army and managed by the Cricket Association of Bengal (CAB), whose headquarters are within the stadium complex.

To me, it isn‚Äôt just a cricket stadium, it‚Äôs a living monument to the sport in India. With a history spanning over 160 years, electrifying crowds, iconic matches, and a rich architectural legacy, it remains the heartbeat of cricketing culture and heritage in Kolkata and across the globe.

An Incredible Experience at Eden Gardens!

Visiting Eden Gardens was an unforgettable experience! The atmosphere in the stadium is electric, especially during big matches. The crowd energy, the cheers, and the overall vibe make it one of the best cricket stadiums in the world. The seating is comfortable, the view from the stands is great, and the facilities are well-maintained. The staff were helpful, and everything was well-organized. A must-visit place for every cricket fan‚Äîtruly the ‚ÄúMecca of Indian Cricket‚Äù!

Eden Gardens is truly massive ‚Äî the crowd, the energy, the atmosphere ‚Äî it‚Äôs mind-boggling.
Every ball bowled is an experience in itself. The stadium is extremely well-managed and located right in the heart of the city.

Tip: Reach at least 30 minutes early or 15 minutes after the match starts to avoid the mad rush.
Best to have a driver or take a cab, as parking can be a hassle.

Food was decent, but nothing exceptional.

What to say about this iconic ground , Lord's may be the mecca of cricket but Eden is the home of cricket ...what a stadium and cricketing venue .

This historical ground witness the evolution of the game ..from the once in a lifetime knock of vvs laxman to carlos brathwaite it has seen it all .

We are so proud to have this venue at our own hometown . And CAB is magnificently maintained its glory as well as modernised it with all the amenities you can expect in a world class cricketing venue .

Electrifying atmosphere‚ö°Ô∏è and surreal viewüôåüèª from the stands with cool gentle breeze from the nearby Hooghly river provides the apt ambience which is sure to set the mood for any cricket lover üôÇ‚Äç‚ÜîÔ∏è.

Witnessed the KKRvsGT match on the 21st April. Though everything was set, but a disappointing game from the home team had left us leaving the stands with a heavy heart üíî

The Eden gardens has improved over time with washrooms and stands renovated, still the dirty washrooms are a major concern (with basins flooded)

Also the seats could be more cleaner. Else everything was fine.

Indeed it is "The Colosseum of Indian Cricket", The Mecca of Cricket" ‚ù§Ô∏èü´∂üèª

sources.snippet: The Park Street Cemetery was one of the earliest non-church cemeteries in the world, and probably the largest Christian cemetery outside Europe and America in the 19th century. Opened in 1767 on what was previously a marshy area, the cemetery was in use until about 1830 and is now a heritage site, protected by the Archaeological Survey of India. The tombs are a mix of Gothic and the rich flavor of the Indo-Saracenic style.

There are lists of rules and regulation which are written behind the ticket please read it before entering. Overall the experience was good, but according to me some more care is needed.
Following are the rules and regulations which is to be followed inside the premises:

‚ô¶Ô∏è Silence to be maintained.

South Park Street Cemetery (a.k.a. Park Street Cemetery) ‚Äî where Kolkata‚Äôs colonial past rests in peace (literally) and history peeks through layers of moss and mist. Established in 1767, this is one of the oldest non-church cemeteries in the world, a silent witness to the city‚Äôs British-era grandeur. Forget horror movies ‚Äî this place is less "The Conjuring" and more "Downton Abbey meets The Jungle Book", with gothic tombs draped in banyan roots and squirrels darting between centuries-old epitaphs.
Among the notable ‚Äúresidents‚Äù here are Sir William Jones, the founder of the Asiatic Society, and Rose Aylmer, the muse of poet Walter Savage Landor (whose love for her was so deep, he wrote a poem that outlived empires). Many tombstones tell tales of lives cut short by tropical diseases, duels, and sometimes, just bad luck in 18th-century Kolkata.
The architecture is stunning ‚Äî grand obelisks, pyramid-like tombs, and intricate carvings that scream Raj-era drama. And if you think cemeteries are spooky, try visiting on a foggy winter morning when the light filters through the trees ‚Äî it‚Äôs eerily beautiful.
Verdict: A hauntingly poetic escape in the heart of Kolkata.
Pro tip ‚Äî Carry a camera, read the inscriptions, and remember, in a city that never sleeps, even the departed have fascinating stories to tell. ü™¶üåøüìú

In the shadows of Park Street Cemetery, the crumbling tombstones beckon a deep contemplation of existence. Each faded inscription speaks of lives once vibrant, now mere whispers lost to time. These graves remind us of the transient nature of our journey‚Äîwhat does it mean to be remembered?

As I traced the weathered stones, I pondered whether significance lies in our deeds or the connections we make. This sacred space urged me to honor the past while reflecting on my own fleeting existence, reminding me that even the most ephemeral moments hold the potential for enduring meaning.

We are just leaves drying with the passage of time and proceeding everyday to the eternal non-existence!

Please don't damage the property and avoid littering, this should be preserved being a great essence to our British Colonial Past!

reviews.reviewText:
Jorasanko Thakur Bari, located in North Kolkata, is the ancestral home of the renowned Tagore family. Built in 1784-85 by Nilmoni Tagore, the house has a rich history and cultural significance. Here's a brief overview:

History
- The land was donated by the Sett family of Burrabazar to Prince Dwarkanath Tagore, Rabindranath Tagore's grandfather.
- The house was expanded by Prince Dwarkanath Tagore and became the residence of the Tagore family.
- Rabindranath Tagore, the first Asian Nobel laureate, was born here in 1861 and spent most of his life in this house.

Architecture and Layout
- The mansion showcases traditional Bengali architecture with a sprawling 35,000 square meter area.
- It features a rounded verandah, allowing family members to watch performances on the natya manch.
- The house has multiple wings, including the Bhdrashan Bari (Maharshi Bhavan) and the Boithak Khana Bari.

Rabindra Bharati University and Museum
- The Government of West Bengal established Rabindra Bharati University in 1961 to commemorate Rabindranath Tagore's birth centenary.
- The university focuses on Indian classical fine arts and quality education.
- The Rabindra Bharati Museum, located within the complex, showcases the history of the Tagore family, their involvement in the Bengal Renaissance, and Brahmo Samaj.
- The museum features over 700 paintings, manuscripts, books, and antique items, including Rabindranath Tagore's original paintings and self-composed wedding invitation card ¬π ¬≤.

Visitor Information
- *Timings:* 10:30 AM - 5:00 PM (closed on Mondays)
- *Entry Fee:* Indians: ‚Çπ20 (adults), ‚Çπ10 (students); Foreigners: ‚Çπ150 (adults), ‚Çπ100 (students)
- *Light and Sound Show:* ‚Çπ50 per person, available in Bengali and English
¬≤ ¬≥

Overall, Jorasanko Thakur Bari is a significant cultural and historical landmark in Kolkata, offering insights into the life and works of Rabindranath Tagore and the Tagore family.

A very peaceful and culturally rich place. Walking through the ancestral home of Rabindranath Tagore feels like stepping back in time. The atmosphere is calm, and the museum gives a beautiful glimpse into the life and legacy of the Tagore family. Highly recommended for anyone interested in history, literature, or just looking for a quiet escape in the heart of the city.

It requires a ticket for entry and a different one to take pictures only from the outside. No inside photography is not allowed. This establishment formulated with many buildings including the living room of Rabindranath Tagore. His daily used things are being displayed here and with his car too. Walking through corridor of the main museum building one could have perception about the lifestyle and type of that time.

Outstanding places for visit and gain knowledge about the heritage and culture about Tagore family

Jorasanko Thakurbari is the ancestral home of the Tagore family, located in Kolkata, West Bengal. It is most famous as the birthplace of Rabindranath Tagore, the Nobel Laureate poet, philosopher, and composer of India‚Äôs national anthem.

History & Significance

Built in the 18th century, the mansion was the residence of the Tagore family, one of Bengal‚Äôs most influential families.

Rabindranath Tagore was born here in 1861 and spent a significant part of his life in this house, where he also breathed his last in 1941.

The house played a crucial role in the Bengal Renaissance, hosting discussions on literature, art, and social reforms.

Attractions & Features

Rabindra Bharati Museum: Showcases artifacts, paintings, manuscripts, and personal belongings of the Tagore family.

Exhibitions on Tagore‚Äôs Life & Works: Depicts his contributions to literature, music, and education.

Cultural Programs & Festivals: Celebrations like Rabindra Jayanti (Tagore‚Äôs birthday) are held with music, dance, and poetry recitals.

Visiting Information

Location: Girish Park, Kolkata.

Timings: Usually open from 10:30 AM ‚Äì 5:00 PM (closed on Mondays).

Entry Fee: Nominal charges for visitors.

Jorasanko Thakurbari is not just a historical site but a symbol of Bengal‚Äôs intellectual and cultural heritage, attracting literature lovers, historians, and tourists alike.
A very beautiful and asthetic place. Everyone should visit once in their life. The price of the ticket is Rs50 but it is only Rs20 for students having I-card.

Review of Jorasanko Thakur Bari ‚Äì Rabindranath Tagore Museum, Kolkata

I was overwhelmed to visit the house where Nobel Laureate Rabindranath Tagore lived with his family.

Tagore is the only person who has composed the national anthem of two countries ‚Äì India and Bangladesh.

This museum is a must-visit for literature enthusiasts and anyone keen to understand Bengali culture and architecture.

The collection includes personal artifacts, photographs, paintings, and Tagore‚Äôs original writings.

The rooms are preserved in their original condition, allowing visitors to envision the environment in which Tagore lived and created his masterpieces.

The red building beautifully exemplifies traditional Bengali architecture.

Photography inside the museum requires an additional fee.

The surroundings are clean and well-maintained, adding to the charm of the place.

The museum is the favourite place of travellers from abroad and the way in which they observed the exhibits and listened to the information about Tagore, explained by the guide....was a moment of pride.

A visit here is not merely a tour of a historic house but a journey into the heart of Bengal‚Äôs cultural and intellectual heritage.

It is an amazing and beautiful place to visit. The ambience there is very peaceful and quiet. The greenery there is also great. Such a beautiful place in the middle of a busy city like Kolkata is mind blowing. The designs and architecture of the buildings are amazing.
Each and every information about Tagore's life has been potraied inside the house. The furniture clothes and other things used by Tagore and his family are also displayed inside.
Overall it was a really nice experience of visiting this place. It is a highly recommended place to visit in Kolkata.
Please do visit this place.

Highly recommended for food lovers and ambiance seekers alike!

Okay! A restaurant can be known for its food but to find an establishment that has a combination of fine food, ambience, excellent service and attention to detail is a rare thing and the Guchhi Restaurant is one such gem. Let‚Äôs start with the restaurant manager Mr. Asif - a professional who knows his guests and his Team. He remembered us from our last visit which was about a year ago. I told him we were going to be entertaining our friends and family whom we had not met in over 40 years for the evening and he right away assigned us an excellent table and with help of his chefs - Chef Satnam and Chef Partha we created a set menu for the evening. Our guests were superbly impressed with the way the food was served in an elaborate sequence. The guests were further in awe when they tasted the Tawa Guchhi, tandoori broccoli, stuffed and grilled  aloos, Bengali fish, chicken makhani, dal Gucchi, paneer labbadar, the dry chrispy okra, raita, the assortments of achaars (especially papaya achar) and a selection of rotis, naans and parathas. The food flowed as if it was an endless supply and our friends were simply blown away with the high quality of the food and service. The guests were further amazed when a selection of delicate paans were served. To boot, the chefs made an appearance to meet our guests and our guests were able to express their sincere gratitude to the chefs for the delicious foods. All in all it was a lovely evening of fine food and great conversation in the comfort of a lovely restaurant. A big thank you to Mr. Asif and his Team. Give this place a shot, you won‚Äôt regret it.

The cathedral stands as an impressive example of colonial architecture alongside the old Writers Building and the Victoria Memorial. Built to accommodate the growing European community, it resembles England's Norwich Cathedral with its pointed arches, buttresses, and vertical piers. St. Paul's Cathedral replaced St.

reviews.reviewText:
St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral is a must-visit for those who appreciate history, architecture and tranquility. With an entry fee of ‚Çπ10, this iconic church offers a peaceful and serene atmosphere that makes you feel instantly at ease.

The Gothic-style architecture is truly stunning with high ceilings, intricate stained-glass windows, and beautifully designed interiors. While photography is not allowed inside, the experience of just sitting there in silence, soaking in the calmness is worth it.

Whether you‚Äôre visiting for prayer, history or just some quiet time, St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral is a perfect escape from the city's hustle. Highly recommended for a peaceful and reflective experience!

St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral in Kolkata is a majestic symbol of Indo-Gothic architecture and colonial heritage. Completed in 1847, it was the first Anglican cathedral built in Asia and remains the seat of the Diocese of Calcutta. Designed by Major William Nairn Forbes and architect C.K. Robinson, its towering spire, pointed arches, and stained-glass windows reflect a blend of Gothic Revival and Indian adaptations suited to the local climate. Located on Cathedral Road near Victoria Memorial and Birla Planetarium, the cathedral is surrounded by lush gardens and offers a serene retreat from the city‚Äôs bustle. Inside, visitors find a high-vaulted nave, intricate woodwork, and frescoes depicting the life of St. Paul.

An architectural masterpiece!
Visiting St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral was an unforgettable experience. The grandeur of the dome, the intricate details in the interior, and the peaceful ambiance make it truly breathtaking. The Whispering Gallery is a unique highlight, and the panoramic view from the top is worth every step. The staff were warm and welcoming, and the entire place is well-maintained. Highly recommend booking tickets in advance to make the entry smooth and hassle-free. A must-visit for history, architecture, and photography lovers!

A Quiet Slice of Heaven in the Heart of Kolkata

If you‚Äôre wandering about Kolkata and fancy a spot of peace and beauty, St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral is the place to be. For just ‚Çπ10, you‚Äôre welcomed into a world of calm that feels miles away from the city‚Äôs buzz.

The architecture is a sight to behold-grand Gothic arches, lofty ceilings, and stained-glass windows that catch the light just right. It‚Äôs not about flashy photos here (they don‚Äôt allow them inside), but rather about the hush in the air, the stillness that settles over you the moment you step in.

It‚Äôs a place to reflect, to breathe, to simply sit and let time slow down. Whether you‚Äôre there for a prayer or just to marvel at the history, this cathedral has a quiet charm that stays with you.

A soul-soothing stop, and one I‚Äôd recommend to anyone craving a bit of grace and serenity.
