Eco Park is truly a breath of fresh air in the heart of Kolkata. Spread across a vast area, it offers something for everyone‚Äîbeautiful gardens, themed zones, a large lake, and plenty of open space to relax or take a long walk. The landscaping is well-maintained and the variety of attractions, like the replicas of the Seven Wonders and boating on the lake, make it an ideal spot for both families and solo visitors. I especially enjoyed the peaceful vibe away from the city‚Äôs hustle. It‚Äôs a great place to unwind, click pictures, or just spend time close to nature. Eco Park in Kolkata is one of the city‚Äôs most beautiful and well-maintained urban parks, offering a perfect mix of nature, leisure, and recreation. Spread over a vast area with a huge waterbody at its center, it provides a refreshing escape from the city‚Äôs hustle and bustle. The park is thoughtfully designed with different themed gardens like the Rose Garden, Butterfly Garden, Mask Garden, and Bonsai Garden, each adding a unique charm to the experience. The Seven Wonders replica section is a major attraction, giving visitors a glimpse of world monuments in one place.

For those who enjoy outdoor activities, Eco Park offers boating, cycling, and a children‚Äôs play area, making it ideal for families. The greenery, clean walkways, and well-arranged sitting areas make it equally enjoyable for morning walkers and evening strollers. Food stalls inside the park serve quick snacks and beverages, ensuring visitors don‚Äôt need to step out for refreshments.

Entry fees are reasonable, and the place is well-managed with proper security and cleanliness. Whether you are with friends, family, or visiting solo, Eco Park is a must-visit destination in Kolkata. It‚Äôs not just a park‚Äîit‚Äôs an experience that combines nature, fun, and relaxation.

reviews.reviewText:
üåüüåüüåüüåüüåü (5/5)

A Slice of Peace in the Heart of Kolkata

Princep Ghat is truly one of Kolkata's most iconic and peaceful spots. The view of the Hooghly River, especially during sunset, is breathtaking. Whether you're on a casual walk, enjoying a boat ride, or simply sitting by the riverside, the atmosphere is calm and refreshing. The white Palladian-style monument is beautifully maintained and adds a historical charm.

Evenings are vibrant with street food vendors, local musicians, and couples strolling hand in hand. It's a perfect blend of nature, history, and local life. The surrounding gardens are clean, and the nearby railway station makes it easily accessible.

Highly recommend visiting if you're in Kolkata ‚Äî don‚Äôt forget your camera, the views are picture-perfect!
Good place to visit for a boat ride in evenings for sunsets. You can also walk here in the garden areas and enjoy the scenic view of river Ganga.

Princep Ghat is one of Kolkata‚Äôs most iconic landmarks and a must-visit destination for both locals and tourists. Located along the banks of the Hooghly River, it beautifully combines history, architecture, and natural beauty. Built in 1843 in memory of the British scholar James Prinsep, the structure boasts stunning colonial-style design and is surrounded by lush green gardens, making it an ideal spot for relaxation and photography. The place is especially charming during the evenings when the Vidyasagar Setu, which looms majestically overhead, is lit up, creating a magical atmosphere.

Visitors can enjoy peaceful walks along the riverbank, take a boat ride for a mesmerizing view of the sunset, or simply sit and watch the gentle flow of the Hooghly. Street food stalls nearby offer delicious local snacks, adding to the experience. It‚Äôs also a favorite spot for couples, families, and photographers due to its scenic charm. The area is well-maintained, with clean surroundings and proper seating arrangements.

Reaching Princep Ghat is easy, as it is well-connected by road and even has a nearby railway station. Early mornings and evenings are the best times to visit, as you can witness the golden hues of sunrise or sunset reflecting on the water. Whether you‚Äôre looking for a peaceful escape, a place to unwind, or a spot to soak in Kolkata‚Äôs heritage, Princep Ghat offers it all. Highly recommended for a serene and memorable experience in the city.

History:
Princep Ghat is a ghat built in 1841 during the British period on the banks of the Hooghly River in Kolkata, India. The Palladian porch was designed by W. Fitzgerald and built in 1843 in memory of the eminent Anglo-Indian scholar and antiquarian James Prinsep.

Note for tourists :
Princep Ghat and its surroundings are really beautiful. Especially the view of Vidyasagar Bridge from this ghat adds extra charm. This place is also considered as a shooting spot. This place is a great place for couples.
You can enjoy a comfortable boat ride at Princep Ghat in Kolkata. If you are a couple or with friends or family, you can rent an entire boat for yourself. You need to fix the boat rent before riding.

I really enjoyed my visit to Princep Ghat.  There's a walkway that runs parallel to the Ganga ‚Äî perfect for a leisurely stroll, a heart-to-heart chat, or even just some quiet reflection with the breeze in your hair and the holy river beside you.

The ghats aren‚Äôt continuous so you can't differentiate them (math joke). In fact, the statement is entirely opposite in English. You can differentiate only when they are not continuous. Strange subjects!

Scattered along the way are small eateries and chai stalls, perfect for grabbing a snack or sipping a hot cup of tea while watching the the river at the end of its more than 2k km journey.

One of the best places to go to see the natural beauty and scenery of this place is mesmerizing. You can spend some time on the bank of Hoogly river and take a boat ride. The best go beyond the hustle and bustle of the city. There is too much greenery and many food stalls here that serve much delicious food .

This location, which is on the banks of the River Hoogli, has a beautiful park and boating facilities.James Princep is commemorated by a monument.A very excellent spot for evening leisure. There are food stands there. The setting sun is stunning.
The Ganges-banks and Princep Ghat have been improved and made more beautiful during the current regime. Previously haunted by criminals, these locations are now a safe and lovely place to take an evening stroll, a refreshing dip, or to perform rituals in an orderly and respectful manner.

Princep Ghat is a serene and picturesque destination that is perfect for a relaxing boat ride with stunning views of the sunset. The lush greenery surrounding the area creates a beautiful and peaceful ambiance, making it an ideal spot to unwind and take in the natural beauty of the surroundings. The tea stalls in the area serve some delicious tea, adding to the experience and making it a perfect spot to spend an evening with friends, family and love once.

Overall, Princep Ghat is an excellent destination for those looking for a calm and enjoyable experience away from the hustle and bustle of city life. The beautiful surroundings, serene atmosphere, and fantastic tea stalls make it a must-visit spot for anyone looking for a relaxing evening in Kolkata.

South Park Street Cemetery is a fascinating historical site in Kolkata with beautifully designed cemeteries dating back over 200 years. The entry fee is ‚Çπ25 which is well worth it for the experience.

One of the must visit place in Kolkata belonging to the colonial period. It's a nice place to visit to know your history regarding the British empire and British Raj. You can get the tickets in front of the door which costs Rs 25 (normal) and Rs 50 (DSLR + Person). No separates student discount is given by the authority. Videography strictly prohibited inside the premises, even model photography is also prohibited. There are authorised person who will be checking your phone or camera just to check if any video clipping or any model photography is there. There are lists of rules and regulation which are written behind the ticket please read it before entering. Overall the experience was good, but according to me some more care is needed.
Following are the rules and regulations which is to be followed inside the premises:

‚ô¶Ô∏è Silence to be maintained.
‚ô¶Ô∏è The ticket is valid for 2 hours only.
‚ô¶Ô∏è One should keep the ticket unless you get outside the ground.
‚ô¶Ô∏è Alcohol or other narcotics are strictly prohibited.
‚ô¶Ô∏è No split or litre.
‚ô¶Ô∏è‚ô¶Ô∏è Violation of any of these is a punishable offence by law and a spot fine of Rs 500 with legal steps.

The timing of the Cemetery is from 10:00 a.m. to 05:00 p.m. and is open all days.

One of the famous heritage and interesting place to visit in Kolkata .
You can visit anytime here between 10am to 4:30 pm and it remains opens everyday.

South Park Street Cemetery (a.k.a. Park Street Cemetery) ‚Äî where Kolkata‚Äôs colonial past rests in peace (literally) and history peeks through layers of moss and mist. Established in 1767, this is one of the oldest non-church cemeteries in the world, a silent witness to the city‚Äôs British-era grandeur. Forget horror movies ‚Äî this place is less "The Conjuring" and more "Downton Abbey meets The Jungle Book", with gothic tombs draped in banyan roots and squirrels darting between centuries-old epitaphs.
Among the notable ‚Äúresidents‚Äù here are Sir William Jones, the founder of the Asiatic Society, and Rose Aylmer, the muse of poet Walter Savage Landor (whose love for her was so deep, he wrote a poem that outlived empires). Many tombstones tell tales of lives cut short by tropical diseases, duels, and sometimes, just bad luck in 18th-century Kolkata.
The architecture is stunning ‚Äî grand obelisks, pyramid-like tombs, and intricate carvings that scream Raj-era drama. And if you think cemeteries are spooky, try visiting on a foggy winter morning when the light filters through the trees ‚Äî it‚Äôs eerily beautiful.
Verdict: A hauntingly poetic escape in the heart of Kolkata.
Pro tip ‚Äî Carry a camera, read the inscriptions, and remember, in a city that never sleeps, even the departed have fascinating stories to tell. ü™¶üåøüìú

In the shadows of Park Street Cemetery, the crumbling tombstones beckon a deep contemplation of existence. Each faded inscription speaks of lives once vibrant, now mere whispers lost to time. These graves remind us of the transient nature of our journey‚Äîwhat does it mean to be remembered?

As I traced the weathered stones, I pondered whether significance lies in our deeds or the connections we make. This sacred space urged me to honor the past while reflecting on my own fleeting existence, reminding me that even the most ephemeral moments hold the potential for enduring meaning.

We are just leaves drying with the passage of time and proceeding everyday to the eternal non-existence!

Please don't damage the property and avoid littering, this should be preserved being a great essence to our British Colonial Past!

reviews.reviewText:
Jorasanko Thakur Bari, located in North Kolkata, is the ancestral home of the renowned Tagore family. Built in 1784-85 by Nilmoni Tagore, the house has a rich history and cultural significance. Here's a brief overview:

History
- The land was donated by the Sett family of Burrabazar to Prince Dwarkanath Tagore, Rabindranath Tagore's grandfather.
- The house was expanded by Prince Dwarkanath Tagore and became the residence of the Tagore family.
- Rabindranath Tagore, the first Asian Nobel laureate, was born here in 1861 and spent most of his life in this house.

Architecture and Layout
- The mansion showcases traditional Bengali architecture with a sprawling 35,000 square meter area.
- It features a rounded verandah, allowing family members to watch performances on the natya manch.
- The house has multiple wings, including the Bhdrashan Bari (Maharshi Bhavan) and the Boithak Khana Bari.

Rabindra Bharati University and Museum
- The Government of West Bengal established Rabindra Bharati University in 1961 to commemorate Rabindranath Tagore's birth centenary.
- The university focuses on Indian classical fine arts and quality education.
- The Rabindra Bharati Museum, located within the complex, showcases the history of the Tagore family, their involvement in the Bengal Renaissance, and Brahmo Samaj.
- The museum features over 700 paintings, manuscripts, books, and antique items, including Rabindranath Tagore's original paintings and self-composed wedding invitation card ¬π ¬≤.

Visitor Information
- *Timings:* 10:30 AM - 5:00 PM (closed on Mondays)
- *Entry Fee:* Indians: ‚Çπ20 (adults), ‚Çπ10 (students); Foreigners: ‚Çπ150 (adults), ‚Çπ100 (students)
- *Light and Sound Show:* ‚Çπ50 per person, available in Bengali and English
¬≤ ¬≥

Overall, Jorasanko Thakur Bari is a significant cultural and historical landmark in Kolkata, offering insights into the life and works of Rabindranath Tagore and the Tagore family.

Highly recommended for anyone interested in history, literature, or just looking for a quiet escape in the heart of the city.

Jorasanko Thakurbari is the ancestral home of the Tagore family, located in Kolkata, West Bengal. It is most famous as the birthplace of Rabindranath Tagore, the Nobel Laureate poet, philosopher, and composer of India‚Äôs national anthem.

History & Significance

Built in the 18th century, the mansion was the residence of the Tagore family, one of Bengal‚Äôs most influential families.

Rabindranath Tagore was born here in 1861 and spent a significant part of his life in this house, where he also breathed his last in 1941.

The house played a crucial role in the Bengal Renaissance, hosting discussions on literature, art, and social reforms.

Attractions & Features

Rabindra Bharati Museum: Showcases artifacts, paintings, manuscripts, and personal belongings of the Tagore family.

Exhibitions on Tagore‚Äôs Life & Works: Depicts his contributions to literature, music, and education.

Cultural Programs & Festivals: Celebrations like Rabindra Jayanti (Tagore‚Äôs birthday) are held with music, dance, and poetry recitals.

Visiting Information

Location: Girish Park, Kolkata.

Timings: Usually open from 10:30 AM ‚Äì 5:00 PM (closed on Mondays).

Entry Fee: Nominal charges for visitors.

Jorasanko Thakurbari is not just a historical site but a symbol of Bengal‚Äôs intellectual and cultural heritage, attracting literature lovers, historians, and tourists alike.
A very beautiful and asthetic place. Everyone should visit once in their life. The price of the ticket is Rs50 but it is only Rs20 for students having I-card.

Review of Jorasanko Thakur Bari ‚Äì Rabindranath Tagore Museum, Kolkata

I was overwhelmed to visit the house where Nobel Laureate Rabindranath Tagore lived with his family.

Tagore is the only person who has composed the national anthem of two countries ‚Äì India and Bangladesh.

This museum is a must-visit for literature enthusiasts and anyone keen to understand Bengali culture and architecture.

The collection includes personal artifacts, photographs, paintings, and Tagore‚Äôs original writings.

The rooms are preserved in their original condition, allowing visitors to envision the environment in which Tagore lived and created his masterpieces.

The red building beautifully exemplifies traditional Bengali architecture.

Photography inside the museum requires an additional fee.

The surroundings are clean and well-maintained, adding to the charm of the place.

The museum is the favourite place of travellers from abroad and the way in which they observed the exhibits and listened to the information about Tagore, explained by the guide....was a moment of pride.

A visit here is not merely a tour of a historic house but a journey into the heart of Bengal‚Äôs cultural and intellectual heritage.

Overall it was a really nice experience of visiting this place. It is a highly recommended place to visit in Kolkata.
Please do visit this place.

Entry Fee: Free
Timings: Open 24 hours; best visited during sunrise or sunset
Nearest Metro: Esplanade / Maidan
Nearest Railway Station: Prinsep Ghat Station

üèõÔ∏è Historical Significance
Prinsep Ghat, built in 1843 in memory of James Prinsep, is one of the oldest and most iconic ghats in Kolkata. The structure features elegant Greek and Gothic style architecture with white columns that reflect the colonial charm of British-era Kolkata. It has been beautifully maintained and restored, making it a picturesque heritage site.

üåâ Scenic Beauty
Located on the banks of the Hooghly River, Prinsep Ghat offers breathtaking views of the Vidyasagar Setu (Second Hooghly Bridge).

The ghat is especially popular during sunrise and sunset hours, when the sky reflects magical hues over the river.

The entire riverside area is clean and well-maintained, with a 2 km stretch of gardens, walkways, benches, and lamp-lit pathways.

üö£ Activities to Enjoy
Boat Rides: Traditional wooden boats are available for short river rides (‚Çπ200‚Äì‚Çπ500). Evening rides under the illuminated bridge are highly recommended.

Photography: Ideal spot for photography lovers‚Äîdaylight or twilight.

Food Stalls: Enjoy local street food like puchka, jhalmuri, egg rolls, and ice cream from vendors nearby.

Evening Strolls: A favorite for couples, families, and solo visitors for a quiet walk along the riverside.

üëç Highlights
Peaceful and scenic atmosphere

Heritage architecture blended with natural beauty

Excellent spot for relaxation, photography, and leisure

Easy access via public transport

üëé Points to Note
Can get crowded in the evening, especially on weekends

Limited restroom facilities nearby

Boat rides are informal‚Äînegotiate prices beforehand

‚úÖ Overall Experience
Prinsep Ghat is a must-visit destination in Kolkata for those who love nature, heritage, and riverside serenity. Whether you're looking to relax, take photographs, enjoy a boat ride, or watch the sunset, this place offers a refreshing break from the city's hustle.

Prinsep Ghat is a historic and scenic riverside promenade located along the banks of the Hooghly River in Kolkata, West Bengal. Built in 1841 during the British Raj, it features a Palladian-style monument constructed in 1843 to honor James Prinsep, a British scholar renowned for deciphering ancient Indian scripts like Brahmi and Kharosthi

Architectural Significance
The monument, designed by W. Fitzgerald, showcases Greek and Gothic architectural elements with its elegant white columns and classical design. It stands as a testament to Kolkata's colonial heritage and is a popular spot for photography and leisurely strolls

Activities & Attractions
Visitors to Prinsep Ghat can enjoy:‚Äã
Riverside Walks: A picturesque pathway along the river, ideal for evening strolls.‚Äã
Boat Rides: Traditional boat rides on the Hooghly River, especially enchanting at sunset.‚Äã
Local Delicacies: Street food vendors offering popular snacks like bhelpuri and ice cream.‚Äã
Photography: Capturing views of the Vidyasagar Setu (Second Hooghly Bridge) and the river.‚Äã

Accessibility
Prinsep Ghat is easily accessible via the Kolkata Circular Railway, with the nearby Prinsep Ghat Railway Station. It's also a short distance from the Esplanade Metro Station, making it convenient for both locals and tourists .‚Äã

Visitor Information
Entry Fee: Free‚Äã

Best Time to Visit: Evenings, to experience the sunset and the illuminated bridge.‚Äã

Facilities: Well-maintained lawns, seating areas, and food stalls enhance the visitor experience.

A Peaceful Evening at Prinsep Ghat, Kolkata

There‚Äôs something quietly magical about Prinsep Ghat‚Äîand this photo really says it all. Nestled along the banks of the Hooghly River, this place becomes pure poetry after sunset. The iconic Vidyasagar Setu stands tall in the background, its lights casting shimmering reflections on the water. You‚Äôll often find little boats bobbing gently nearby, their canopies glowing softly under the moonlight.

What makes Prinsep Ghat special isn‚Äôt just the view‚Äîit‚Äôs the feeling. The cool breeze, the sound of water lapping against the shore, and the distant hum of the city create this peaceful pocket where time seems to slow down. Whether you‚Äôre out for a quiet walk, deep in thought, or simply sitting by the water with a cup of chai, it‚Äôs the kind of place that lets you breathe a little deeper.

There‚Äôs no rush here. People come with friends, with loved ones, or alone‚Äîand somehow, everyone finds a little calm. You‚Äôll see couples talking quietly on benches, photographers capturing long-exposure shots of the bridge, and boatmen offering rides across the glowing river.

If you ever find yourself in Kolkata, take an evening to visit. Trust me, it‚Äôs more than just a pretty view‚Äîit‚Äôs a moment you‚Äôll carry with you.

My Take: Peaceful, scenic, and perfect for slowing down.
When to Go: At sunset. The city lights reflecting on the water? Unreal.
Don‚Äôt Miss: A boat ride under the bridge and grabbing some street snacks near the riverside.
Nice place to spend the evening, just don't try the overpriced river boats here as the sunset time in the evening is great to spend some time on the river bank

sources.snippet: Kolkata's famous Park Street (formally renamed as Mother Teresa Sarani) runs from Chowringhee Road to Park Circus and is renowned for its entertainment, restaurants, and prominent historical landmarks including old colonial mansions. This iconic street was home to India's first independent nightclub and has been the center of Kolkata's nightlife since the glory days of the swinging 60s when venues overflowed with jazz, cabaret, and floor shows. Head to Mocambo, Moulin Rouge and Trincas for a rush of nostalgia.

reviews.reviewText:
The Indian Museum is a must-visit destination for history lovers and culture enthusiasts. It houses an incredible collection of artifacts from ancient times, including sculptures, fossils, coins, textiles, and more. The Egyptian mummy and the grand Buddhist galleries are particularly fascinating.

The museum is quite large, so give yourself at least 2‚Äì3 hours to explore it properly. It can get a little warm inside during summer months, so I recommend visiting in winter for a more comfortable experience. Overall, it's an enriching and educational experience that offers a glimpse into India‚Äôs vast and diverse heritage.

I love exploring museums and have visited museums across all major Indian cities, and I can say with confidence that this is the finest museum in India, at least from my experience. The collection is vast and incredibly diverse, showcasing historic items and antiques from across time and geography. The star attraction is the 4000 year old Egyptian mummy in the Egypt Gallery, which is truly fascinating. Apart from that, the museum also houses remarkable Buddhist archaeological treasures from Gandhara (present-day Kandahar, Afghanistan), along with fascinating galleries on fossils, zoology, birds, geology and what not. The Botany Survey of India is also part of this museum, adding to its richness and diversity. I would recommend keeping at least 2‚Äì3 hours aside to explore properly. This museum is a journey through both history and culture, and an absolute must visit.

Visiting the Indian Museum was an enlightening and enjoyable experience!

Every gallery tells a unique story, and I learned so much, especially in the Zoological and Egyptian sections, which were my favorites‚Äîtruly captivating!

The museum is a paradise for history buffs and curious travelers, offering a deep dive into India‚Äôs rich heritage and beyond.

The museum is conveniently located near Park Street Metro, making it super accessible.

However, the ticket prices are a bit steep for college students, and there are extra charges for mobile phone photography.

The cafeteria prices, though, are quite reasonable.

I highly recommend taking your time to explore this inspiring and educational gem.

Had a great time with my buddies!

It‚Äôs a journey through time that‚Äôs well worth taking, imperfections and all.

I just amazed by seeing this type of collection. First I checked painting and then the real things the bones of the animals. It really feels like my ticket is worth of it.

I truly suggest to visit it.

Founded in 1814 at the cradle of the Asiatic Society of Bengal (at the present building of the Asiatic Society, 1 Park Street, Kolkata), Indian Museum is the earliest and the largest multipurpose Museum not only in the Indian subcontinent but also in the Asia-Pacific region of the world.

I visited the Indian Museum on 23rd August 2022, and it was my very first time exploring this historic treasure-and truly, it was an amazing experience.

From ancient artifacts to rare sculptures, fossils, and cultural exhibits, every section of the museum tells a fascinating story. Walking through its grand halls felt like stepping into a time machine-rich with history, knowledge, and artistic beauty. I was deeply impressed by the vast collection and the way everything was preserved and presented.

As someone with a love for history and culture, this visit was both inspiring and educational. I captured some memorable photos during my tour, but the real magic is something you have to experience in person.

If you‚Äôre ever in Kolkata, a visit to the Indian Museum is an absolute must. Whether you‚Äôre a curious traveler or a history enthusiast, you‚Äôll leave with a deeper appreciation of South Asia‚Äôs rich heritage.

Great place filled with history and here the time speaks. The ancient artifacts and other elements would drug to the past. It would  reveal India's ancient glory. Walking through the ground floor of the museum it might appear that the people of the past weren't less intellect than us and even their appetite exceeds ours in some cases. The magnificent stone work would left the viewer speechless. No need to buy tickets in advance and  interestingly buying a photography ticket one can get permission of taking photos almost all the things though rate is different for mobile camera and digital cameras.

The Indian Museum, Kolkata, is a true treasure and a must-visit for anyone who loves history, art, and culture. Being the oldest and largest museum in India‚Äîand even in Asia‚Äîit offers a fascinating journey through time. From rare fossils, ancient coins, and archaeological wonders to stunning paintings, stuffed animals, skeletons, and even an Egyptian mummy, every section has something to amaze you.

It‚Äôs not just for history lovers‚Äîkids will find it fun and educational too. The location is excellent, with easy connectivity via metro and buses. Tickets are reasonably priced, and you‚Äôll find helpful facilities like a baggage counter, clean toilets, and a cafeteria.

A tip: banned items such as matches, cigarettes, and gutkha are not allowed, so leave them at home. Mobile photography is allowed if you purchase a photography pass.

If you want to enjoy the full experience, set aside at least 3‚Äì4 hours‚Äîyou‚Äôll leave with memories and knowledge that will stay with you forever!

The museum has an impressive collection and a lot of interesting exhibits, especially if you‚Äôre into history and archaeology.
Most of all I liked miniature paintings collection on the second floor.
However, it‚Äôs very hot inside ‚Äî they don‚Äôt use air conditioning, so be prepared if you‚Äôre visiting during warmer months. Worth a visit, but could be more comfortable.

Nicco Park in Kolkata is a popular amusement park that offers a fun-filled experience for visitors of all ages. Here's what you can expect:

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Nicco Park is without a doubt one of the best attractions in Kolkata for a fun-filled day with family and friends. From the moment you step inside, you‚Äôre greeted with a lively atmosphere, lush greenery, and well-organized pathways that make the entire park easy to explore. It truly lives up to its nickname ‚Äî the "Disneyland of the East."

The variety of rides here is impressive. Whether you‚Äôre an adventure seeker who loves high-speed roller coasters and the Cyclone ride, or someone who prefers calmer experiences like the cable car or toy train, there‚Äôs something for everyone. The park maintains high safety standards, and you can see staff actively ensuring that rides are operated smoothly and securely.

The Water Park section is a highlight in itself ‚Äî perfect for cooling off on a warm day. The wave pool, water slides, and lazy river are all well-maintained and super fun. Kids absolutely love the splash zones, and adults can enjoy the slides just as much.

Another great thing about Nicco Park is the cleanliness. You‚Äôll find dustbins at regular intervals, and the staff are quick to keep the area neat. There are also plenty of food stalls offering everything from snacks to full meals, with both local and international options. The prices are reasonable for the quality and convenience.

It‚Äôs not just about rides ‚Äî Nicco Park also has beautiful gardens, a small aquarium, and various fun activities that make it more than just an amusement park. You can easily spend an entire day here without feeling bored.

Overall, Nicco Park offers excellent value for money and delivers an experience that‚Äôs enjoyable for people of all ages. It‚Äôs a must-visit in Kolkata if you‚Äôre looking for adventure, entertainment, and a bit of nostalgia all in one place.

Nicco Park is a great place for a fun-filled day with family and friends. It offers a wide variety of rides and attractions, especially for kids and young adults. The main amusement park has some exciting rides and scenic spots, and the water park is definitely a highlight, especially during the summer.

However, it can get very crowded on weekends, especially in the water park section. Be prepared for long queues for most of the popular rides. If you're planning a visit, weekdays might be a better option for a more relaxed experience.

The food at the caf√© inside was surprisingly good‚Äîfresh and tasty with decent options for both snacks and meals. One thing to note is that basic items like bottled water are sold at a premium‚Äîa 1-liter bottle costs ‚Çπ50, which feels a bit overpriced.

Overall, Nicco Park offers a memorable day out, especially for families, but planning ahead and visiting on a less busy day can make a big difference.

Nicco Park is by far the best amusement park in Kolkata. I‚Äôve visited countless places in the city, but none have given me such consistent joy throughout the entire day. The park is very well maintained as it is clean, organized, and run with great attention to detail. The staff are always friendly, helpful, and attentive to safety, which makes the experience even more enjoyable.

With nearly 40‚Äì45 attractions to explore, there‚Äôs something for everyone. I recommend booking tickets online in advance and opting for the combo with the waterpark entry; it usually costs around ‚Çπ1200 year-round, and you can sometimes find special offers at about ‚Çπ600. Do keep in mind that food, certain rides, games, lockers, and bowling are charged separately.

For the best experience, plan to arrive early (around 11 AM) so you have enough time to enjoy all the rides. If you‚Äôre visiting the Wet-o-Wild waterpark, make sure to bring synthetic clothing as required. The only downside is the food‚Äîthe options at the food courts are consistently disappointing, so don‚Äôt expect much in that department.

That said, whether you‚Äôre with friends, family, or a partner, Nicco Park guarantees a day full of thrill, adventure, and plenty of laughter. It‚Äôs the perfect place for anyone looking to create fun and memorable experiences.

Nicco Park: A Day of Fun and Thrills in Kolkata!
Nicco Park in Salt Lake, Kolkata, is an outstanding amusement park that promises a day filled with fun and excitement for everyone. To get the most out of your visit, it's wise to book in advance to save money, especially since the queue for tickets can be quite long.
The park offers a fantastic variety of thrilling rides that cater to adrenaline junkies, and the water park with its fun slides is a perfect way to cool off. For the little ones, the toy train is a great choice, providing a delightful ride around the park.
Beyond the rides, the food stalls are also good, offering a range of tasty snacks to keep you energized. The boat ride was a fun and relaxing experience, perfect for winding down. Nicco Park truly offers an enjoyable experience with family and friends, making it a great destination for all ages. It's the ideal place for a memorable day out!

This is an average amusement park. As I have been to amusement parks at Bangalore and chennai, I felt this was a medium to average size park only. The only scary ride was the Tornado (the roller coaster). All other rides were enjoyable without any fear even, the Sky dive was not that scary.  Still we had a great time. Food prices inside are higher. The water bottle cost is 50rs.

Nicco Park is a great place for fun and relaxation in Kolkata. It has a good mix of thrilling rides, family attractions, and a water park that‚Äôs perfect in summer. Clean, well-maintained, and enjoyable for both kids and adults. Can get crowded on weekends, but overall a must-visit spot.‚Äù

Nicco Park, Kolkata is truly a fun-filled destination for families, friends, and thrill-seekers alike. Known as the ‚ÄúDisneyland of West Bengal,‚Äù it offers a wide range of rides ‚Äî from adrenaline-pumping roller coasters and water slides to gentler options like the toy train and cable car. The park is clean, well-maintained, and has beautiful green spaces that add to its charm. The food stalls inside serve decent snacks at reasonable prices. Whether you‚Äôre visiting for the water park, amusement rides, or just to relax, Nicco Park guarantees a memorable day.

reviews.reviewText: Eden Gardens is the only Venue for International Cricket matches and IPL matches in Kolkata, West Bengal. It is always a treat to watch a Cricket match in Eden Gardens Cricket Stadium. It is managed by Cricket Association of Bengal( CAB). One of the ancient and nostalgic cricket stadiums in India. This stadium is famous for the enthusiasm of the Cricket Lovers and fans. The atmosphere is always electric as it remains forever...

Eden Gardens in Kolkata is a place every cricket fan dreams of visiting. Known as the ‚ÄúMecca of Indian cricket,‚Äù this iconic stadium can hold over 60,000 people, and the energy here is simply electrifying during a live match. The roar of the crowd, the sight of cricketing legends on the field, and the sheer scale of the arena make it unforgettable. Even if you are not a huge cricket follower, stepping inside gives you goosebumps because of its history and atmosphere. Outside the stadium, the Eden Gardens park offers a calm contrast, with shady trees and a small lake perfect for a quiet walk. A visit here blends passion, history, and the thrill of being part of something larger than life.

If cricket had a Heaven in India, then Eden Gardens would be it. This isn‚Äôt just a stadium ‚Äî it‚Äôs an emotion, a coliseum where legends are made, dreams are shattered, and 66,000+ voices chant in unison, shaking the very ground. Established in 1864, Eden Gardens is India‚Äôs oldest and second-largest cricket stadium, often called the ‚ÄúLords of the East‚Äù (but let‚Äôs be honest, even Lord‚Äôs can‚Äôt match the madness of an India-Pakistan match here!).
The roar of the crowd when Sourav Ganguly waved his shirt at Lord‚Äôs? That energy was born here. Sachin‚Äôs records, Dhoni‚Äôs helicopter shots, and Kolkata Knight Riders‚Äô IPL triumphs? All celebrated under Eden‚Äôs floodlights.
But Eden Gardens isn‚Äôt just about cricket. The Maidan surrounding it is Kolkata‚Äôs green lung, where footballers, morning walkers, and political rallies coexist in perfect chaos. Nearby, the Rabindra Sadan-Nandan cultural complex fuels Bengal‚Äôs love for theatre and films, while the Mohan Bagan, Mohammedan Sporting and East Bengal football clubs remind you that Kolkata‚Äôs second religion is football.
And then there‚Äôs the Eden Gardens Park, a serene escape with a picturesque lake, along with the pagoda, perfect for a quiet evening stroll (assuming you aren‚Äôt still hoarse from screaming at a match).
Verdict: Whether you love cricket or just the thrill of history, Eden Gardens is a must-visit.
Pro tip ‚Äî Catch a live match here; the energy is electric, and the crowd could out-cheer a rock concert!

Eden Gardens ‚Äì The Mecca of Indian Cricket!
Located in the Maidan area near BBD Bagh, right opposite the Calcutta High Court, this is a legendary venue that resonates deeply with the soul of cricket.

I have visited the stadium five times, and among those, the first-ever pink-ball Day-Night Test match between India and Bangladesh left a lasting impact on me. The stadium, with an approximate seating capacity of 68,000, was packed to the brim that day. During the event, I had a brief conversation with a ground staff member who shared info that the boundary dimensions are approximately 66‚Äì68 meters on the square side and 76‚Äì78 meters on the straight side.

The stands inside the stadium are named after cricketing legends such as Sourav Ganguly, Pankaj Roy, and Jagmohan Dalmiya. The B.C. Roy Club House named in honor of former West Bengal Chief Minister Dr. B.C. Roy.

While attending matches, you might experience cellular connectivity issues due to the presence of signal jammers. However, vendors selling water and snacks are quite efficient. There are also food corners and canteens inside the stadium offering decent food, albeit at higher-than-usual prices.

One area that consistently falls short is crowd management. In my experience, the gathering process lacks professionalism. A stadium of such iconic status should ideally have more streamlined crowd-control mechanisms.

For your information I want to let you know that Eden Gardens is owned by the Eastern Command of the Indian Army and managed by the Cricket Association of Bengal (CAB), whose headquarters are within the stadium complex.

To me, it isn‚Äôt just a cricket stadium, it‚Äôs a living monument to the sport in India. With a history spanning over 160 years, electrifying crowds, iconic matches, and a rich architectural legacy, it remains the heartbeat of cricketing culture and heritage in Kolkata and across the globe.

An Incredible Experience at Eden Gardens!

Visiting Eden Gardens was an unforgettable experience! The atmosphere in the stadium is electric, especially during big matches. The crowd energy, the cheers, and the overall vibe make it one of the best cricket stadiums in the world. The seating is comfortable, the view from the stands is great, and the facilities are well-maintained. The staff were helpful, and everything was well-organized. A must-visit place for every cricket fan‚Äîtruly the ‚ÄúMecca of Indian Cricket‚Äù!

Eden Gardens is truly massive ‚Äî the crowd, the energy, the atmosphere ‚Äî it‚Äôs mind-boggling.
Every ball bowled is an experience in itself. The stadium is extremely well-managed and located right in the heart of the city.

Tip: Reach at least 30 minutes early or 15 minutes after the match starts to avoid the mad rush.
Best to have a driver or take a cab, as parking can be a hassle.

Food was decent, but nothing exceptional.

What to say about this iconic ground , Lord's may be the mecca of cricket but Eden is the home of cricket ...what a stadium and cricketing venue .

This historical ground witness the evolution of the game ..from the once in a lifetime knock of vvs laxman to carlos brathwaite it has seen it all .

We are so proud to have this venue at our own hometown . And CAB is magnificently maintained its glory as well as modernised it with all the amenities you can expect in a world class cricketing venue .

Electrifying atmosphere‚ö°Ô∏è and surreal viewüôåüèª from the stands with cool gentle breeze from the nearby Hooghly river provides the apt ambience which is sure to set the mood for any cricket lover üôÇ‚Äç‚ÜîÔ∏è.

Witnessed the KKRvsGT match on the 21st April. Though everything was set, but a disappointing game from the home team had left us leaving the stands with a heavy heart üíî

The Eden gardens has improved over time with washrooms and stands renovated, still the dirty washrooms are a major concern (with basins flooded)

Also the seats could be more cleaner. Else everything was fine.

Indeed it is "The Colosseum of Indian Cricket", The Mecca of Cricket" ‚ù§Ô∏èü´∂üèª

Review of Birla Mandir, Kolkata

I recently had the opportunity to visit Birla Mandir in Kolkata, and it was truly a serene and spiritually uplifting experience. The temple's white marble architecture is both majestic and elegant, standing tall as a symbol of peace and devotion in the heart of the city.

The moment I stepped inside the premises, I was struck by the calm and clean environment. The intricate carvings on the walls and ceilings reflect exquisite craftsmanship and devotion. The temple is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and his consort Lakshmi, and the sanctum radiates a divine aura that makes one pause and reflect.

The beautifully maintained gardens, well-laid pathways, and the peaceful ambience made my visit very pleasant. Though photography isn‚Äôt allowed inside, the mental images of the serene interiors and the melodious temple bells will stay with me for a long time.

The temple is usually less crowded in the mornings and early evenings, which is when I would recommend going if you want a peaceful darshan. The security arrangements and cleanliness are commendable. It‚Äôs also conveniently located and easy to reach by public or private transport.

In short, Birla Mandir is not just a place of worship but a quiet retreat from the city‚Äôs hustle ‚Äî perfect for spiritual seekers, architecture lovers, or anyone in need of a moment of calm.

The iconic Birla Temple of Kolkata isn‚Äôt just a temple ‚Äî it‚Äôs an architectural marvel wrapped in white marble and glowing in divine serenity. Built by the renowned Birla family, this *22-year labor of love was finally completed in 1996, and let‚Äôs just say, the wait was worth it! Dedicated to Lord Krishna and Radha, the temple stands as a modern masterpiece that blends spirituality with intricate craftsmanship.
Walking in, you‚Äôre greeted by the rhythmic chants of devotees, the cool touch of spotless marble, and a sense of peace that feels almost unreal in Kolkata‚Äôs usual chaos. The walls and pillars are adorned with detailed carvings from Hindu scriptures, making the place feel like an open book of mythology ‚Äî except this one is sculpted in stone.
Interesting fact: At night, the temple lights up like a celestial palace, with golden hues reflecting on its pristine white domes, making it one of the most photogenic spots in the city. Inside, the beautiful idols of Radha-Krishna, Shiva-Parvati, and Ganesha shimmer under soft lighting, adding to the temple‚Äôs divine ambiance.
Verdict: A must-visit for peace-seekers, architecture lovers, and anyone who appreciates a spiritual escape.
Pro tip ‚Äî Visit in the evening for the breathtaking illumination and a peaceful *darshan*. Who knew divinity could be this Instagrammable? üôè‚ú®üì∏

The temple is very beautiful. But I didn‚Äôt see any sign saying that photography is not allowed. When I went to take a photo of the idol, the security guard started shouting loudly. This is not the right way. If photography is not allowed, then please put a board like other temples do.

This temple got Built by the Birla family, the temple‚Äôs construction spanned 26 years, from 1970 to its inauguration in 1996 .
It is Designed by Nomi Bose, it occupies about 2 acres and rises to a height of 160 feet .
The architecture is an exquisite mix of Nagara-style and Rajasthani temple design, echoing motifs from the Lingaraj Temple of Bhubaneswar and the Lakshmi Narayan Temple .
Constructed with sandstone exteriors and white marble interiors, the temple walls feature intricate carvings illustrating scenes and shlokas from the Bhagavad Gita, while the ceiling dazzles with chandeliers and electric diyas .
The main shrine houses lovely Krishna and Radha idols, crafted from marble, often richly adorned .
Side shrines are dedicated to Durga, Shiva, Hanuman, Ganesha, and the ten avatars of Vishnu .
Daily worship hours run from 5:30 AM to 11:00 AM and 4:30 PM to 9:00 PM, with a particularly serene and devotional feel during the evening aarti .
Festivals such as Janmashtami, Radhashtami, Holi, and Diwali are celebrated with vibrant rituals, music, and great devotion .

Birla Mandir Ballygunge is a breathtaking blend of traditional and modern architecture, crafted from pristine white marble with intricate carvings. Dedicated to Lord Krishna and Radha, the temple exudes a peaceful and spiritual ambiance, perfect for reflection and worship. Its glowing lights at dusk create a magical atmosphere, making it a must-visit landmark in Kolkata for both devotees and tourists seeking beauty and serenity in one place.

Indian Coffee House at College Street is a timeless gem that perfectly captures the essence of Kolkata's intellectual and cultural heritage. Surrounded by bookstores and the academic buzz of College Street, the vibe here is simply unmatched. The old-world charm, lively conversations and nostalgic ambiance make it a must-visit spot.

The food was equally delightful especially the chicken cutlet, mutton kabiraji and cold coffee which were all fantastic. The flavors were rich and the crispiness of the kabiraji was just perfect. The service was warm and efficient adding to the overall great experience.

Had a wonderful time soaking in the history, the energy and the flavors. If you're in Kolkata, this place is a must-visit!

Absolutely rude staff, trying to push us out even before we finished our food.
Food dint taste good either.

But , if in vicinity, recommend visiting (order only tea/coffee) - for this particular magnificent window which looked other-worldly when we visited around 12.30pm

(We visited in November 2024)

This is one of Kolkata‚Äôs most nostalgic places, filled with rich history. However, the food quality is disappointing. I have been here twice mainly to soak in the nostalgia and though I tried different dishes, the taste was just average. Once known for good coffee and food, the quality has sadly deteriorated over the years, and the staff‚Äôs behavior is not very welcoming either.

Still, it holds a unique charm. You will often find elderly groups sitting here, continuing their adda sessions that began during their college days, sometimes 50‚Äì60 years ago. For that sense of history and continuity, it‚Äôs worth a visit at least once but go for the nostalgia, not the food or the coffee.

Chicken cutlet coating was very thick. The chicken inside seemed uncooked. Cold coffee was terrible, with more water than coffee. Chicken chowmein veggies were undercooked. Hygiene and cleanliness is a bit of concern. Too hot inside. Fans are not of much use. That way prices are a bit on the higher side.

A must-visit spot with a charm of its own! On the way, you‚Äôll find numerous bookstores‚Äîa true heaven for book lovers. The aura of the place is completely different and worth experiencing. I ordered a cold coffee; it was good, though not the best. Still, this place definitely deserves a spot on your Kolkata must-visit checklist ‚úÖ

Indian Coffee House, Kolkata ‚Äì A Sip of History Amidst College Street's Charm

Located at the heart of College Street, Asia‚Äôs largest second-hand book market, Indian Coffee House in Kolkata is not just a caf√© ‚Äî it‚Äôs a living piece of history. Once the adda spot for legends like Subhash Chandra Bose and Rabindranath Tagore, this place still holds on to its old-world charm with pride.

The moment you step in, you‚Äôre transported to a bygone era. The vintage interiors, high ceilings, and simple wooden furniture are unchanged. Outside, the slow-moving trams, iconic yellow taxis, and the bustling book stalls of College Street only add to the nostalgic experience.

Despite being packed most of the time, the service is quick, and the coffee is strong and satisfying ‚Äî just as it should be. It's easy to sit here for hours, soaking in the ambience and imagining the powerful debates and historic conversations that once filled the air.

Highly recommended ‚Äî not just for the coffee, but for a beautiful peek into Kolkata‚Äôs intellectual and cultural legacy.

Indian Coffee House in Kolkata is more than just a caf√©‚Äîit's an institution that carries the legacy of intellectual conversations, history, and an old-world charm that is hard to find elsewhere. Located in the bustling College Street area, this iconic coffee house has been a meeting place for students, artists, and intellectuals for decades.

The ambiance is vintage, with high ceilings, wooden furniture, and an air of nostalgia that transports you back in time. It‚Äôs not about luxury but about an experience steeped in history and culture. The service is simple yet warm, adding to the charm of the place.

Coming to the coffee, their signature Infusion Coffee and Cold Coffee are must-tries. The menu also offers classic snacks like Chicken Cutlet, Egg Toast, and Mutton Afghani, all at pocket-friendly prices. It‚Äôs a great place to sit back, sip coffee, and watch the world go by.

If you‚Äôre looking for a place that offers more than just food‚Äîa place that tells stories and sparks conversations‚ÄîIndian Coffee House is a must-visit in Kolkata.

Rating: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê (5/5)

This place breathes history‚Äîstepping in feels like stepping back in time, wrapped in the warm haze of nostalgia.
But alas, the culinary offerings are a tragedy. The very soul of a caf√©‚Äîits coffee‚Äîis its greatest flaw.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: St. John's Church, located in the heart of Kolkata, is a historic cathedral built in 1787 by the East India Company. It was funded through a public lottery and became the first Parish Church of Bengal. In 1815, it was designated as the primary Cathedral of Kolkata until St. Paul's Cathedral was consecrated in 1874.
placeMetadata.address: 2/2, Council House St, opp. Dewars Garage, Lal Dighi, B.B.D. Bagh, Kolkata, West Bengal 700001, India

reviews.reviewText: One of the oldest churches in the Kolkata region, this gem is a must-visit for history buffs and anyone fascinated by the colonial era. While waiting for official work nearby, we decided to explore it‚Äîand it was worth every moment. With an entry fee of just ‚Çπ10, you‚Äôll step into a beautifully preserved piece of history. The peaceful shrine, regular mass services, stunning architecture, and vintage paintings make it a serene and enriching experience. Highly recommended!

St. John's Church is not commonly talked about‚ÄîI wasn‚Äôt even aware of it myself. But visiting it left me amazed. If there is any church in Kolkata that can rival St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral in size and beauty, it is this one. The church is situated on a spacious premises, about a 10‚Äì15 minute walk from BBD Bag Station and just 2 minutes from the Kolkata High Court. The entry fee is ‚Çπ10 per person. It is a serene and well-maintained place. Apart from the church itself, the premises also house a monument, the tomb of Lady Canning, various paintings, and statues. A visit here is certainly worthwhile for everyone. The church remains open every day except Sunday, from 10 AM to 4 PM. The peaceful environment makes it a perfect place to experience calm and tranquility.

St John's Church Kolkata:
Located in Council House Street, near Raj Bhavan.
St. John‚Äôs Church is the third oldest Church of Kolkata.
The land was donated by Maharaja Naba Krishna of Sovabazar. The foundation stone was laid by Governor-General Warren Hastings. Funds for the construction of the church were raised through a public lottery. St. John‚Äôs Church was opened to the public in 1787 and was designed by architect James Agg of Bengal Engineers.
St. John‚Äôs Church, with its 174 feet high clock tower.
The Church was built on a graveyard, so the compound has several tombs and memorials, but only a couple of them are older than the church itself.
It houses the following tombs; Job Charnock‚Äôs Mausoleum,decorated memorial of Lady Canning, The compound also houses the controversial Calcutta Black Hole Memorial, Second Rohilla War Memorial and several other graves.
Entry fee Rs.10.00 per head.
**

This church was the former cathedral of the Anglican Church. It was one of the first buildings to be built by the east India company. The site used was a graveyard which also houses the tomb of Job Charnock. Lady Canning‚Äôs
Memorial, the Rohilla War memorial and the black hole
Memorial are also on the grounds, besides some other graves and tombstones.
The chair of Warren Hastings, the then governor, is also in a room on the grounds.
In the church, one can see the 200 year old pipe organ and the famous painting of the last supper

An interesting fact about this church is that the land was donated by Maharaja Naba Kishan Bahadur of the Sobhabazar Royal Family to Warren Hastings. The church is serene and peaceful, with beautiful neoclassical architecture. There is also a small entry fee of ‚Çπ10.

St. John‚Äôs Church, built in 1787, is one of Kolkata‚Äôs oldest churches and a landmark of the city‚Äôs colonial heritage. Constructed by architect James Agg, it served as the city‚Äôs first Anglican cathedral until 1847 and stands as a testament to the British East India Company‚Äôs architectural influence...
The church features a beautiful art of the Last Supper on its interior wall along with a large pipe organ adding a spiritual and artistic dimension. Its outside garden is serene, lined with historic graves, including the memorial of Job Charnock, considered the founder of Kolkata, and other notable figures, giving visitors a sense of the city‚Äôs layered past...
Built with Chunar sandstone and bricks, featuring a 174-foot spire and a prominent clock tower. The surrounding grounds combine peaceful greenery with solemn memorials, creating a reflective atmosphere...
Open daily from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM and modest attire is recommended. A visit to St. John‚Äôs Church offers a unique blend of history, art, and colonial-era architecture, making it a must-visit for anyone exploring Kolkata‚Äôs heritage...

Nestled quietly at the northwest corner of Raj Bhavan (BBD Bagh), St. John‚Äôs Church immediately envelops you in a calm, almost reverent ambiance. Despite being surrounded by Kolkata‚Äôs bustling heart, the lush green courtyard‚Äîwith its tall trees, soft grass, and occasional playful squirrels‚Äîfeels like an oasis of serenity .Designed by Lt. James Agg of the Bengal Engineers and modeled after London‚Äôs St Martin-in-the-Fields, this neoclassical gem was built between 1784 and 1787 . Its stone structure‚Äîbuilt from rare stones shipped from the medieval ruins of Gour‚Äîis why it's affectionately known as ‚ÄúPathure Girja‚Äù (‚ÄúStone Church‚Äù) .

Its most striking feature is the 174-ft tall stone spire crowned by a massive clock, which serves as both a landmark and a timeless centerpiece . The grand portico, lined with Doric or Corinthian columns, ushers visitors into a space that exudes architectural dignity and grace .

Though most of the people of Kolkata only knows about St.Pauls Cathedral church,there are many more churches around kolkata to visit.
At BBD Bagh,there is a beautiful church,named St.John's Church amidst a peaceful environment.
A few mintute walk through the path covered with gravel will feel like time has been stopped.
There is also the mausoleum of Job Charnock,the founder of the city Kolkata.
At the time of Christmas, this church being decorated nicely to celebrate.

reviews.reviewText:
Visited Millennium Park in Howrah and had a great experience, especially with the boat ride, which was the highlight of the visit. The ride was smooth and enjoyable, and the ticket price was incredibly affordable‚Äîjust Rs. 6 for a one-way trip, making it a great value for money.

The park itself is a nice place to relax by the river, but the atmosphere was quite humid, which made it a bit uncomfortable to stay for long, especially during the day. Despite that, it's a good spot for a quick outing, and the boat ride alone makes it worth visiting.

It is a wonderful location for an afternoon stroll. While there was an initial entry fee of ‚Çπ20, access to parks 2 and 3 is now completely FREE. Park 1, however, is reserved for official visits. Furthermore, all the rides have been temporarily removed. Although the amphitheater is often utilized by roller skaters, it remains available for various artistic performances. Overall, it is a delightful place to relax and uplift one's spirits.

Millennium Park is a peaceful and scenic spot perfect for a relaxing walk by the riverside. The view of the Ganges, especially during evening, is absolutely stunning. It‚Äôs clean, well-maintained, and has plenty of seating areas to just sit and enjoy nature. The palm trees and soft lighting in the evening create a beautiful ambiance. Great place for photography too.

Millennium Park is a beautiful riverside park that offers a peaceful escape in the middle of the city. The walking paths are clean and lined with palm trees, making it ideal for morning or evening strolls. The view of the river is absolutely stunning, especially under a bright blue sky. A perfect place for families, couples, or anyone looking for a calm and scenic spot.

Millenium Park is a go-to place for the people living in Kolkata. The park boasts well-landscaped gardens, clean walkways lined with palm trees, and plenty of benches from which you can admire stunning views of the Howrah and Vidyasagar bridges especially beautiful at sunset.

However, the park is not well maintained at all. Uncleanliness is evident everywhere within the park.

We went for a electric water metro ride- Dheu however all the tickets were sold. As I believe, one door closes yet opens uo another one. We explored the Millennium Park. It was a rainy afternoon. The park was empty offering a lush green view. Most of the rides which were once an eye-catcher were dilapidated and counting on their last days. The shabby ticket counter called upon us to remind of its golden busy days. Broken things although looks sad has their own way of showing beauty, that it is okay to let go and hold onto the memories buried in the crevices. The trees were happy though, the leaves getting to dance upon the drizzle. We had a good time with everything.

Millennium Park located at Strand Road, Kolkata, on the banks of the Hooghly River. The park is 2.5km long and lies on Hooghly‚Äôs eastern shore opposite to the Railway Club and near the Fairlie Ghat. You can easily view the¬†Howrah Bridge¬†from the park. The park is located in the BBD Bagh area of Kolkata, near the¬†General Post Office¬†and the Calcutta High Court.
The park has been beautified with a variety of trees and lots of pretty lights. The view of the Hooghly waterfront and the Howrah Bridge from the park makes Millennium Park worth a visit. A variety of activities at Millennium Park include:

Opening time- 10.00 AM- 6.30 PM/daily and entry fee- RS. 10.00.

Millennium Park ‚Äì Where the Sun Whispers Goodbye in the City‚Äôs Glow

Millennium Park isn‚Äôt just a place‚Äîit‚Äôs a feeling. As the sun begins to dip, the park blushes in gold. Trees glow, the Hooghly shimmers, and the city gently slows its pace. In these golden hours, the park unveils its quiet magic.

The air turns softer, laughter warmer, and even silence feels romantic. Couples find cozy corners, steps grow slower, and hearts sync with the sunset. With the majestic river flowing beside and Howrah Bridge bathed in amber light, it‚Äôs a moment that belongs in poetry.

Perfectly couple-friendly, the park offers breezy walkways, inviting benches, and peaceful views made for long conversations. That view of the setting sun behind the bridge? Pure magic.

Whether you‚Äôre walking hand in hand, watching the sky change, or just soaking it all in‚ÄîMillennium Park at golden hour is Kolkata‚Äôs softest love story.A must-visit for romantic souls and golden-hour chasers.

reviews.reviewText:
If you‚Äôve ever been stuck behind a tram on a busy Kolkata street and grumbled about its pace, Smaranika Tram Museum will make you rethink your irritation. Housed inside a restored 1938 tram, this charming little museum at Esplanade is where Kolkata‚Äôs iconic trams hit the brakes ‚Äî literally and historically!
What‚Äôs on Track?
1. A Tram Ride to the Past ‚Äì Smaranika (meaning ‚Äòsouvenir‚Äô) takes you on a ticketed journey through time, showcasing Kolkata‚Äôs tram history, dating back to 1873, when horse-drawn trams ruled the city! It‚Äôs a bit like time travel, but with wooden seats.

2. Tickets, Tokens & Timeless Tales ‚Äì From vintage punched tickets to old conductor uniforms and route maps, the museum brings alive the golden era when tram conductors actually issued paper tickets instead of just swiping smart cards.

3. Tram Caf√©? Yes, Please! ‚Äì One half of the tram serves as a mini caf√©, where you can sip on tea and munch on snacks while pretending you‚Äôre in the early 1900s. Best part? The food is priced as affordably as tram tickets!

Final Stop: For ‚Çπ20, this museum is cheaper than your daily commute and far more enjoyable! Whether you‚Äôre a history buff or just want a unique Instagram story, Smaranika is a must-visit for a true-blue Kolkatan experience!

Ok...because Entry to the Tram is closed due to repairs.
Basically the Tram museum is 2 refurbished now defunct tram coaches that are installed inside a park near the Esplanade Tram depot.
Ok..because it felt nice to have a look at the refurbished tram from outside...would have loved to have a look at it from inside, but this also means that I have to make one more visit to the tram museum to visit the tram from inside and give it a 5 star.

One of the most underappreciated museums you will ever see is this one, which I visited yesterday. The entrance fee is just 20/-, and each person will have 45 minutes.  Here, you can enter a tram and learn about Kolkata's tram history. This is a must-see location for tram lovers. There is an uncle inside the tram who will tell you about its history and sell you coffee and biscuits.
Overall, I would like to give it a solid 9 out of 10.

RAJBHAVAN- NEAREST LANDMARK

Hi..
Kolkata is the only city in India with a working, albeit declining, tram service.

Smaranika is a small cafe-museum set up a few years ago at the Esplanade tram terminal. It consists of a restored tram parked in its own enclosure. The front car has a few tiny tables where one can sip tea or coffee (and perhaps munch on biscuits or chips ‚Äì there is a very limited menu). The rear car ‚Äì which can be entered only through the front car ‚Äì has a display of old photographs, a few old uniforms, old tickets and tokens, etc. The exhibits seem rather neglected and do not seem to attract many visitors except for diehard fans.

Nearest Metro: Esplanade Gate no

Timing: 1pm to 8pm (Thursday closed)

Follow me on Instagram for more
IG: @_haque_fiza_

The ticket costs Rs. 20/- and permits you to stay there for 45 minutes ‚Äì perhaps they want to discourage visitors from lounging there for too long! Incidentally, the ticket itself is designed to look like a tram ticket (see photo) and it serves as a souvenir of your visit. Also it's closed every Thursday.

Unfortunately they do not permit photography inside the museum space. But now it is permissible. However, I clicked a couple of photos outside the fencing, which I am posting here.

Thank You üòä

An applaudable initiative to celebrate the heritage of Kolkata ‚Äì tram. The Smaranika Tram Museum in Kolkata, located inside a restored vintage tram at Esplanade, offers a unique glimpse into the city‚Äôs historic tram network‚Äîthe oldest in Asia. Established in 2014, the museum showcases rare artifacts like old tickets, conductor uniforms, mechanical parts, and vintage photographs that trace the evolution of trams from horse-drawn to electric. One part of the tram houses a cozy caf√©, while the other serves as the museum space. Open daily (except Thursdays), it‚Äôs a charming blend of history and nostalgia, celebrating Kolkata‚Äôs enduring relationship with trams and preserving a key part of the city‚Äôs cultural identity.

Anyways despite the no photography allowed people were still taking pics and all so I took some shots as well,  it'd okish to be there if you are in the area its a normal park and since it closes off at 4 you cant spend the evening there.

An oasis in the heart of Kolkata‚ÄîElliot Park is where the city slows down and breathes.

Tucked just behind Tata Centre and a 2-minute stroll from Maidan Metro Station, Elliot Park is one of those rare green pockets that balances urban buzz with serene calm. Whether you‚Äôre escaping office stress, walking off a heavy lunch from Park Street, or just craving silence in the city‚Äîthis place delivers.

Why Elliot Park stands out üåø

1. Immaculately maintained: The walking tracks are clean, the lawns are manicured, and the benches are never too crowded. A welcome surprise, especially in central Kolkata!

2. Perfect for walkers and joggers: The circular path is wide, shaded, and ideal for early morning jogs or evening strolls. You‚Äôll find fitness enthusiasts, seniors, and college students all vibing in harmony.

3. Green escape with skyline views: While you enjoy the chirping birds and tall trees, the distant silhouette of downtown Kolkata peeks through‚Äîbest of both worlds.

4. Safe and peaceful: Entry is free but secure. It feels family-friendly, with couples, kids, and elderly visitors all coexisting without any nuisance.

Extras that make it special:

Photography alert: Visit around 4:30‚Äì5:30 PM for golden light filtering through the trees‚Äîideal for portraits or casual reels.

Proximity bonus: Maidan Metro, Victoria Memorial, and St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral are all within walking distance. Makes for a beautiful half-day circuit.

No hawkers inside = clean experience. But don‚Äôt worry‚Äîthere‚Äôs always a bhel puri or tea stall right outside the gates when hunger hits.

Heads-up ‚ö†Ô∏è

Closed on Mondays for maintenance.

No food or loud music allowed‚Äîthis is a calm space, not a picnic ground.

Limited shaded seating‚Äîcarry a cap if you're visiting in the afternoon.

Local tip: Carry a book or some headphones and let the world slow down. If you‚Äôre a working professional, this is your go-to spot for a reset. If you‚Äôre a tourist, it‚Äôs the quiet pause you didn‚Äôt know you needed between Victoria and Park Street.

Elliot Park is proof that in the middle of chaos, Kolkata still has places that let you just... be.

If this review helped you find your new favorite spot, tap that üëç Helpful button and show some love for the city's green lungs!

placeMetadata.address: Strand Rd, B.B.D. Bagh, Kolkata, West Bengal 700021, India

reviews.reviewText:
Ah, the iconic Babughat! The name itself is a delightful throwback to Kolkata‚Äôs aristocratic past ‚Äî imagine a zamindar with a monocle sipping cha while discussing Shakespeare and share prices. Built in 1830 by Rani Rashmoni, the original boss lady of Bengal, Babughat isn‚Äôt just another riverside stop ‚Äî it‚Äôs the ultimate throwback Thursday in stone and soul.

With its Greek-Doric columns and faded colonial charm, Babughat is like an old photograph that refuses to yellow with time. It was once a posh bathing ghat for the ‚Äúbabus‚Äù of yesteryear ‚Äî hence the name ‚Äî and over the years, it has morphed into an eclectic hotspot for everyone from temple-goers to ticket-checkers.

What‚Äôs the Buzz at Babughat?
- It‚Äôs a multi-tasking marvel ‚Äî part ghat, part transit hub, part protest ground, and fully Kolkata. One minute you‚Äôre watching a political rally; the next, it‚Äôs a flower-seller‚Äôs market.
- The Colonial portico structure is one of the last remaining neoclassical gems still clinging to dignity despite buses honking their way around it.
- It‚Äôs one of the most active immersion ghats during Durga Puja, where goddesses and goodbyes meet in a crescendo of conch shells and camera flashes.

The Real Experience:
The ghat is less about peace and more about poetry in motion. You‚Äôll find priests chanting, pigeons cooing, lovers whispering, and sadhus contemplating life ‚Äî or possibly lunch. It‚Äôs chaotic, colorful, and charmingly cluttered ‚Äî a microcosm of Kolkata‚Äôs soul with a splash of river nostalgia.

And let‚Äôs not forget the iconic launches that ferry passengers across the Hooghly from here. If you haven't taken a boat ride from Babughat to Howrah at sunset, you're seriously missing out on one of Kolkata‚Äôs cheapest and most cinematic experiences.

Kolkata Recommends:
Get there early to beat the bustle, click a few sepia-toned shots, grab a "jhalmuri" from a moustachioed vendor, and let the Hooghly whisper tales of colonial Calcutta and modern madness.

Verdict:
Babughat isn‚Äôt just a place ‚Äî it‚Äôs a state of nostalgia. Slightly weathered, eternally poetic, and always ready for its close-up.

It is the second oldest ghat in Kolkata and is known for its colonial-era architecture, including a tall structure with Greek-style pillars. The ghat served as a busy spot for ferry services and is also a popular location for religious rituals.

sources.snippet: The New Market, also known as the Hogg Market, is always one of the busiest areas in the city. Right in the center of Kolkata, you‚Äôll find rows of shops selling clothes, jewelry, electronics, leather, household items, flowers, sweets and more. The unique red-brick market hall contains over 2,000 stalls in all.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: New Market Area, previously known as Hogg Market, is a historic shopping destination in Kolkata that dates back to 1874. It was initially established to cater to the needs of British residents and has since become a beloved arcade for locals and visitors alike. The area boasts a mix of street food stalls offering delicious phuchka, chat, and desi Chinese cuisine alongside branded retail food joints like KFC and Dominos.

placeMetadata.name: Rabindra Sarani

sources.snippet: There is so much to see and do here in Rabindra Sarani, in the northern part of Kolkata, which is lined with historical buildings, stunning archways of the impressive Nakhoda Mosque and numerous minarets. Discover the incredible stories associated to them, allow yourself to immerse into the eternal hustle and bustle in former Chitpur Road, Kolkata‚Äôs oldest street, and its backstreets, with crowds of people that are a staggering blend of different ethniticities. All this in an urban world so rich in contrasts and blends, where futuristic and very traditional modes of transport try to complement each other in the way of poverty-reflecting rickshaws and shiny glam cars.
sources.shortName: Your Street Photography Workshop Guide to Kolkata (2024)

sources.snippet: Reportedly the former residence of Rabindranath Tagore ‚Äì hence the name ‚Äì Rabindra Sarani is perhaps the most recommended street photography destination in the city. Considering this bit of history, it‚Äôs no surprise that the spot is dotted with luxurious residences with a tinge of yesteryear colonial character. Its lanes, meanwhile, are lined with shops offering everything from sandesh and chaa to attar and ayurvedic medicines.
sources.shortName: Capture The Charm Of Kolkata At These 7 Street Photography Spots

sources.snippet: Shops selling itar (perfume oil) and hakeemi medicine (herbal medicines), ancient eateries and timeworn saree showrooms are scattered all over Rabindra Sarani. Also known as Chitpur in its earlier days, it was home to several palatial residences of wealthy Bengali babus (merchants). The cacophony of rickshaws, trams, autos and cars bustling amidst the crowds of people and dilapidated shops, is ever present.
sources.shortName: Kolkata Street Photography Places, Places for Photography in Kolkata

placeMetadata.name: Dakshineswar Kali Temple

sources.snippet: This old and very popular Hindu temple, dedicated to Bhavatarini ("savior of the universe", an aspect of Goddess Kali), was founded in 1855 by Rani Rashmoni. Widowed at a young age, she very successfully took over her wealthy husband's zamindar (land ownership) business. Apparently, the idea to establish the temple came to her in a dream before a pilgrimage to Varanasi.

reviews.reviewText: This place provides a beautiful experience for the kids so schools often choose this place for conducting their field trip. It offers so many things to see and learn. It even has a good capacity to hold large number of people. The place runs a canteen too.

Visited after many years. Last visited when I was a child. They have upgraded in every aspects.  My daughter enjoyed a lot. Though she is too small to understand many things, but she enjoyed cold mine show, 3D show, Science Magic show, things she understand and gaming zone specially for below 7 years old.

Parking is available,  elevator available,  wheelchair entrance is there, bathrooms are clean. They have also a canteen in very reasonable rate. Taste & quantity is ok, could have been better in this price point.

Highly recommended. Try to visit in weekdays for less crowd.

Absolutely wonderful place for children to learn science and understand scientific and natural phenomenon in a fun way. There are variety of pavilions displaying various items of scientific interest. The scientific officers and staffs are very helpful, friendly and knowledgeable. They explain the various items on display with love and care to the children. These people do not discriminate based on caste, religion, gender, social and economic condition. The displays are meticulously maintained. There's a cafeteria inside. Large groups of children can be taken to this museum for whole day trip

A pretty good place to visit mostly due to the vast collection of technology revolution displays and the illustrative method of knowledge sharing with a simple twist of creating awareness in the end. Example: they spoke about energy sustainability and the need to conserve it in our personal lives at the end of the coal mine show. Focusing on how difficult, risky and capital intensive mining is. With an explanation of why coal mining is unsustainable and the fact they still feed a majority of our thermal power plants for electricity generation.
The only issue is that a good number of equipment and display screens don't work. The upkeep is poor as in most state maintained facilities and that affects the overall learning journey.
That said, there's still plenty to explore and learn.
We thoroughly enjoyed the visit and highly recommend it especially for children and even the younger population.

It was great to be back at my favorite science museum after 4 decades. All most all the exhibits where changed. Displayed subjects were revamped with changing times. Took my granddaughter who seems to have enjoyed the visit. The shows like coal mine and 3 d movie where of particular interest.

A revisit to ones school days......a must visit for every science lover....

Its better to buy a package for INR 90 and spend a good time to recharge our mental faculties with the wonders of science.....

Divided into several sections .....each gives  a comprehensive view of the multi facets of science.......live models....detailed notes ....a mock coalmine trip......3D shows.....a fun show on science.....a treatise on Nobel laureates and science luminaries......

Tucked away in the heart of Bara Bazar, Kolkata, the Nakhoda Masjid stands as a majestic reminder of the city‚Äôs rich cultural and architectural heritage. This historic mosque, built in the early 20th century, is one of the oldest and most significant Islamic landmarks in the area. With its grand domes, intricate carvings, and striking red sandstone facade, the mosque is nothing short of breathtaking.

Despite the hustle and bustle of the surrounding marketplace, the moment one steps into the mosque premises, a sense of peace and calm washes over. The spacious courtyard and serene prayer halls offer a quiet escape from the busy world outside. Many people‚Äîlocals and travelers alike‚Äîcome not only to pray but also to sit and rest, reflecting in the tranquil atmosphere.

The Nakhoda Masjid is not just a place of worship but also a symbol of unity and tradition. Its timeless beauty and the soothing environment make it a cherished sanctuary for those seeking spiritual connection or a brief moment of solace. Whether you‚Äôre there for prayer or a pause from the chaos, the mosque welcomes all with its calming embrace.whenever I came to Kolkata I am going there.

Nakhoda Mosque, the largest mosque in Kolkata, is¬†a stunning example of Indo-Saracenic architecture.¬†Built in 1926, it can accommodate 10,000 worshippers and is known for its grandeur and intricate details, including the Buland Darwaza-inspired entrance.¬†Its location in the heart of old Kolkata makes it a prominent landmark and a popular tourist attraction.

[Visited on 13 July, 2025]

Built in 1926 by Abdur Rahim Osman, a merchant from Kutch, Gujarat, the mosque's architecture is inspired by the mausoleum of Mughal Emperor Akbar at Sikandra, Agra.¬†Its gateway resembles the Buland Darwaza at Fatehpur Sikri.

Capacity and Features:

The Nakhoda Masjid is the largest mosque in West Bengal and eastern India, with a prayer hall capable of accommodating 10,000 worshippers.¬†It features three domes, two main minarets standing at 46 meters (151 ft) high, and 25 smaller minarets ranging from 30 to 36 meters (100 to 117 ft) in height.

Historical Significance:

The mosque was named Nakhoda, meaning 'mariner', after its founder, Abdur Rahim Osman, who was a prominent shipping magnate.¬†The reconstruction that gave it its current form was completed in 1935, with significant contributions from prominent Cutchi Memons of Kolkata.

Nakhoda Masjid is one of Kolkata‚Äôs most iconic landmarks, known for its stunning Mughal-style architecture and spiritual ambiance. Located in the bustling Chitpur area, this grand mosque is the largest in the city and can accommodate thousands of worshippers.

reviews.reviewText:
History:

Metcalfe Hall is a heritage building located in Kolkata, West Bengal, India. Built between 1840 and 1844, it is named after Sir Charles Theophilus Metcalfe, who served as the Governor-General of India in the 1830s. He was known for his liberal policies and for supporting freedom of the press, which earned him great respect.

The hall was designed in the Greek Revival style, with 30 massive Corinthian columns, giving it a neoclassical look that resembles ancient Greek temples. Initially, it housed the Calcutta Public Library and later the Imperial Library, which eventually became the National Library of India. Today, it serves as a heritage center showcasing Kolkata‚Äôs cultural and historical evolution.

It‚Äôs not a typical tourist hotspot, so it‚Äôs less crowded‚Äîmaking it ideal for a quiet, reflective visit. Entry is usually free, and photography is allowed inside. It‚Äôs especially recommended if you enjoy heritage walks or want a break from the city‚Äôs usual hustle.
