Metcalfe Hall, is a refined tribute to Kolkata‚Äôs colonial past & intellectual heritage, beautifully restored to celebrate both its architectural elegance & the city‚Äôs cultural narrative was originally a library. Once the hall hosted the Calcutta Public Library, featuring near about 5000 books transferred from Fort William & various donations. Dwarkanath‚ÄØTagore served as its first proprietor. The hall became the Imperial Library in 1903 under Lord Curzon, eventually the nucleus of the National Library, which moved to Belvedere House in 1925. Later taken over by the ASI in the year 1992, extensive restoration was completed in 2018‚Äì19 & reopened as an exhibition & cultural space.

This stunning neoclassical Greek-revival was inspired by Athens, modeled after the Ancient Greek‚ÄØTower (Temple) of the Winds, was free of cost earlier when I visited a few years back. The rectangular two-storey hall with five chambers, a majestic western stairway (now closed), and the main entrance on Hare Street is now charged Rs. 20/- per person. At the very first moment you reach, you have to scan the code & pay the said amount. A single person (single payment system) can purchase or pay for five persons at once. Your identity proof (namely Aadhar card or number) is a must for entrance. If people visit in a group, then the identity proof of any one member can be considered valid.

It will take approx 2 hours to completely tour the entire museum. The place is indeed photogenic. You can often find some photographers & vloggers with their models. These things are more or less destroying the peaceful & vintage vibes of the place I guess. Need more maintenance as the visitors knowingly or unknowingly damaged its properties which is not a good sign.

If you're exploring the historic BBD‚ÄØBag area or visiting the Hooghly riverfront, this is a must see, especially for those who appreciate heritage, art & Bengali ethos.

üåâ Biswa Bangla Gate ‚Äì A Modern Landmark in New Town
Biswa Bangla Gate, also known as Kolkata Gate, is a striking architectural structure located in New Town. It features a circular glass viewing gallery suspended above the road, offering panoramic views of the area. The design is modern and eye-catching, especially when lit up at night.

Visitors can enjoy a quiet walk inside the air-conditioned glass gallery, which displays exhibits related to Bengal‚Äôs culture. The gate also houses India‚Äôs first hanging restaurant, where guests can dine above the city with a scenic view. Entry to the gallery requires an advance online booking.

‚úÖ Final Thoughts:
Biswa Bangla Gate is a unique attraction that combines art, architecture, and cityscape views. It‚Äôs a great place for photography, a casual visit, or a special dining experience. Clean, safe, and well-maintained‚Äîdefinitely worth a visit if you're in New Town.

reviews.reviewText:
Amidst the architectural splendor of Kolkata‚Äôs historic district stands the iconic Town Hall, an imposing neoclassical structure that has witnessed the city‚Äôs transformation from the capital of British India to the cultural epicenter of modern Bengal. Built in 1813-14 during the British Raj, Town Hall was once the beating heart of intellectual discourse, elite gatherings, and civic events. Today, it remains a significant landmark, echoing tales of Kolkata‚Äôs rich past while embracing its evolving future.

An Architectural Masterpiece
Designed by Colonel John Henry Garstin, the Town Hall is an impressive Greco-Roman structure, featuring tall Doric columns, grand staircases, and a vast central hall. The building's majestic fa√ßade, made of chunar sandstone and brick, exudes an aura of colonial elegance, making it one of the finest examples of 19th-century British architecture in India.

The hall, spanning 12,000 square feet, was originally built to serve as a venue for European aristocrats, bureaucrats, and merchants to host balls, banquets, and official meetings. However, over time, its role evolved, and it became a hub for public discourse, political debates, and literary events.

A Storied Past
- Town Hall‚Äôs early days: It was exclusively meant for the British elite, with Indians largely restricted from entering.
- Freedom Movement connections: By the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the Town Hall became a meeting ground for Indian intellectuals, reformists, and nationalist leaders, discussing ideas that shaped the independence movement.
- Post-independence evolution: After India gained independence, the hall transitioned into a civic and cultural center, hosting exhibitions, conferences, and public events.

Fascinating Facts About Town Hall
- In 1897, Swami Vivekananda delivered a powerful lecture here after his triumphant return from the West.
- Kabiguru Rabindranath Tagore, along with other literary and political figures, frequently attended discussions at this venue.
- The Town Hall Museum, added in the 21st century, showcases a digital archive of Kolkata‚Äôs history, featuring rare maps, documents, and photographs.

A Historic Treasure in Need of Attention
Despite its historical significance, Town Hall has faced periods of neglect, with structural wear threatening its grandeur. However, in recent years, restoration efforts by the Kolkata Municipal Corporation have revived its lost charm, ensuring that this colonial jewel continues to stand tall.

Today, Town Hall remains a symbol of Kolkata‚Äôs intellectual and political legacy, a place where history whispers through its walls, urging the present to remember its past.

reviews.reviewText:
A Peaceful and Inspiring Visit.  I recently visited The Mother House of the Missionaries of Charity in Kolkata, and it was a deeply moving experience. The serene atmosphere and the presence of Mother Teresa's tomb create a sense of peace and reverence. The museum, which displays her personal belongings and relics, offers a glimpse into her humble life and dedication to serving the poorest of the poor.

The staff were courteous and respectful, ensuring that visitors could reflect and pray in a tranquil environment. The daily Mass at the chapel is a beautiful experience, and the museum's exhibits are both informative and inspiring.

This place is not just a tourist spot but a pilgrimage for those who admire Mother Teresa's work and legacy. It's a must-visit for anyone looking to find some inner peace and learn about the incredible humanitarian efforts of Mother Teresa and her sisters.

The entry is free and there are shops nearby selling souvenirs.

Review of Mother House, Missionaries of Charity ‚Äì Kolkata

Among all the places I visited in Kolkata, Mother House left the most lasting impression on my heart. Nestled in a modest lane of the bustling city, this place radiates peace, simplicity, and divine presence. It is the headquarters of the Missionaries of Charity, founded by Saint Mother Teresa, and visiting here felt like stepping into a sacred space of love and humility.

The sisters welcomed everyone with warmth and grace. They gently guided us through the areas open to visitors ‚Äì the tomb of Mother Teresa, the chapel where she used to pray, and the museum, which preserves many of her personal belongings. The museum is simple yet powerful ‚Äì you‚Äôll find her worn sandals, handwritten letters, rosaries, her iconic white and blue saree, the awards she received, and deeply moving quotes that reflect her selfless mission.

One of the most touching moments was seeing Mother Teresa‚Äôs own room ‚Äì a tiny space with just a simple bed, a table, and no fan. It was a striking reminder of her vow to live among and like the poorest of the poor. Even today, the sisters live in the same humble manner ‚Äì I saw them drawing water with buckets from a tank below, living a life of complete simplicity and service.

People from across the world visit to seek peace, offer prayers, and draw strength from the legacy of Mother Teresa. Many, including myself, have experienced miraculous blessings after praying to her. There‚Äôs a quiet sense of healing and hope in the air ‚Äì the kind that words can barely capture.

While Kolkata has many attractions, Mother House is a place that touches the soul. It‚Äôs not just a tourist spot ‚Äì it‚Äôs a spiritual home that holds unforgettable memories and a timeless message of love and compassion.

Going to Mother Teresa's Home was a really unique experience. Unlike the other big tourist spots in Kolkata, this isn't about grand architecture or loud crowds. It's a place that just feels different. As soon as you step inside the gates, the noise of the city seems to just fade away.

The main thing to see is Mother Teresa's tomb, which is incredibly simple and beautiful. People are kneeling and praying, and the atmosphere is so peaceful and respectful. It's a very powerful place for quiet reflection. The small museum is interesting, too, with some of her personal belongings and a little history on the Missionaries of Charity.

It's not a place you'll spend hours and hours at, but you don't need to. It's a quick, quiet visit that leaves a lasting impression. It's a nice change of pace from the typical Kolkata sightseeing and a powerful reminder of her legacy. If you're looking for a moment of peace and a chance to feel connected to a truly remarkable person, it's absolutely worth a visit.

reviews.reviewText:
Belur Math is a peaceful haven nestled in the heart of Kolkata, where spirituality and natural beauty come together in perfect harmony. The quiet surroundings, elegant structures, and lush greenery make it an ideal place to pause, breathe, and reconnect with yourself.

Whether you‚Äôre visiting to sit in silence, admire the architecture, or just enjoy a quiet moment by the Hooghly River, the place welcomes everyone with a gentle calmness. There‚Äôs a sacred feeling in the air‚Äîas if the presence of Sri Ramakrishna, Maa Sarada, and Swami Vivekananda still flows through the campus.

The main temple beside the Ganga is especially mesmerizing. Watching the river drift by while you sit in stillness is an experience that stays with you. Bhog is served in the morning (before 11 AM), but it‚Äôs good to come early to avoid the long queue. There are many quiet corners under the trees where you can simply sit and reflect.

The entire premises are spotless and beautifully arranged, making it perfect for a peaceful walk with family or time alone. It‚Äôs truly a place that helps you disconnect from life‚Äôs noise and feel inner peace. Just check the timings before you go‚Äîthe temple is open from 6:30 to 11:30 AM and again from 3:30 to 8:30 PM.

Words may fall short‚Äîbut the experience speaks for itself.

üåü A Soulful and Serene Experience at Belur Math, Kolkata üåü
Visiting Belur Math was a truly peaceful and enriching experience. Located on the banks of the Hooghly River, this spiritual headquarters of the Ramakrishna Mission is not just a place of worship but a symbol of harmony and inner peace.

The campus is extremely clean, well-maintained, and beautifully landscaped. The main temple's architecture is unique ‚Äî it combines Hindu, Christian, and Islamic motifs, reflecting the teachings of Sri Ramakrishna about the unity of all religions. The atmosphere inside the temple is calm and meditative.

One of the highlights of the visit was the museum inside the Math premises, which gives deep insights into the lives and teachings of Sri Ramakrishna, Swami Vivekananda, and Sarada Devi. It's a must-visit for those interested in Indian philosophy and spiritual thought.

The evening Aarti (prayer ceremony) is mesmerizing and fills the entire space with divine vibrations. The gentle sound of bells, chants, and the serene river breeze create a powerful yet peaceful ambiance.
The staff and volunteers are courteous and helpful. Photography is not allowed inside the temple, which actually helps you disconnect from distractions and connect more deeply with the experience.
Overall Rating: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê (5/5)
Perfect for: Spiritual seekers, history and culture lovers, and anyone looking for peace and inspiration.
Tip: Visit during evening Aarti and take a walk along the riverside garden ‚Äî it‚Äôs magical.

placeMetadata.name: Artsy - Coffee & Culture

sources.snippet: Yes, it‚Äôs true that I would love any place that serves a good avocado toast. But, what makes cafes like Artsy even better are the photogenic walls that seem to attract us Instagrammers without fail. Hidden away in a small lane off a busy street, Artsy coffee and culture is one of my favourite Instagrammable spots in Kolkata.
sources.shortName: The 10 Best Instagrammable Spots In Kolkata

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Artsy Coffee & Culture is a charming cafe tucked away in Minto Park, offering a unique blend of coffee and culture. Lighthouse Cafe in Jodhpur Park hosts photography workshops and showcases world-class literature, while 8th Day Cafe & Bakery serves delectable bagels. Sienna Cafe is known for its healthy avocado toasts and topli nu paneer salads. Hope Cafe in Gariahat not only offers excellent sandwiches but also employs staff from marginalized communities.
placeMetadata.address: Ground Floor, 230/B, Minto Park, Acharya Jagdish Chandra Bose Rd, Sreepally, Bhowanipore, Kolkata, West Bengal 700020, India

reviews.reviewText:
Artsy Coffee & Culture is a charming spot with a well-decorated and inviting ambiance. The staff is attentive and polite, and the service is excellent, with drinking water provided. The latte was delightful, made with freshly brewed coffee beans, featuring lovely latte art and accompanied by a complimentary cookie, which was a nice touch.

The other items we tried were tasty, not overly oily, and quite satisfying. The washroom was clean and well-maintained, and the availability of charging points with chargers makes it convenient for working. While the seating arrangements were limited, we didn't face any waiting time. However, the ergonomics could be improved, as most tables are too low for comfortable use.

It would be great if they added more variety to their menu, including croissants and gluten-free options. A few tweaks, and this place would be perfect!

This is one of the most beautifully decorated cafes with unique foods ans good hospitality in Kolkata. Situated near the AJC Bose Road in between Exide crossing and Minto Park, this cafe offers a good variety of snacks and beverage options. The first thing to mention about this cafe is its excellent artistic ambience. They have all the modern artefacts, paintings ans other exotic decorative staff to give a unique feel inside this cafe. They have a nice book shelf with a very good variety of books but being in Kolkata, Bengali books are definitely missed here. Apart from that, they have charging points and high tables which are quite suitable for work or online meetings. Talking about the menu, we ordered Chicken Vietnamese roll, spicy chicken katsu sandwich and mocha. Among these, the roll was quite unique to taste, it was cold but very delicious due to its unique saucy flavour. The mocha was also very well brewed and good to taste. The lead time of serving was also quite practical. The staff members were very polite, attentive and good listeners. They were quite modest while talking to us, suggesting or taking orders. The washroom was very neat and clean ans well maintained. There are limited seats inside the cafe, once you get in, you will get a nice charming look which is very pleasing and charming. Prices are of course little high and the variety of foods can be improved.

This is the most satisfying restaurant I have been to in Kolkata. It is a hidden place so I did not expect much. However, the interior is stylish and the staff service is good. The best part is the food. All the menus are delicious. Especially the sandwiches made with Panini bread were so delicious. The smoothie bowl was like the acai bowl I had in Hawaii. The pancakes and ice cream on top were also delicious. The tacos were topped with fried avocado. Very classy and delicious. I love this place so much. I've been here 3 times during my trip and have been satisfied every time.

It's late April and the sun is weak yellow, barely holding up against the vast stretch of grey sky, all gloomy over us. Streets were almost empty, the platforms are wet, there has been a persistent rain since morning and people seen rather quiet in conducting their commute-related activity.
Excellent artistic ambience of Artsy cafe and a perfectly complimenting weather is a too good to be true experience. Haha
My friend and I walked out into the rain, our usual Artsy is a walkable distance away from metro station.The cafe is located  somewhere at a turn in a busy bhawanipore street, this place however  is relatively free from the prosaic urban trappings.
We spent a couple of hours being part productive and part laughs and giggles there.
We had  blueberry cheesecake yummy as always and  dark chocolate espresso which was very well brewed.
Have been here twice or thrice, everytime absolute delight. The foood's good, The staff here is praiseworthy of what they do, always polite and sharing smilesüòä
I had a great afternoon there.
I'm always happy to bee here when my people suggests Artsy on day outs.
Well, definitely planning to see Artsy again.‚úåÔ∏è

Went randomly to this 'little plate of heaven' and can't express how beautifully is every dish created by the chef. We ordered Pasta, pancake, burrito bowl and coffee . Every serving was a rush of flavours , freshness and love. Even the service was very prompt and polite. Must visit if u are in Kolkata!

One of the best cafe in Kolkata. Hands down their coffee is one of the best in town. Recommending their salads and roasted chicken as well. Ambience was just perfect. Wish to visit there again and again. Also this is one of the most aesthetic place in town.

I find it overpriced but for experience one can have the taste of their coffee once.. I had frappe and mocha with an pineapple cake slice (nothing special, ordinary vanilla cake with a small slice of caramelized pineapple and a cherry)ambience and service can make your mood lit up.. it's a nice place for hangout and date..

This is my 3rd visit to Artsy.... & hence can say with true vigor that Artsy is one fine spot to unwind & have a hearty talkfest with your dear ones. Love the Sketch Gallery & Book & Souvenir sectionals. Also, very amiable staff.

placeMetadata.description: Traditional, domed planetarium & observatory featuring astronomy shows in multiple languages.

reviews.reviewText: The Birla Planetarium in Kolkata, established in 1963, offers an engaging gateway to the cosmos. Designed in a distinctive Indian architectural style inspired by the Sanchi Stupa, it stands as one of the largest planetariums in Asia. Visitors can enjoy well-structured shows in multiple languages (English, Hindi, and Bengali) with impressive graphics and sound that bring the wonders of the universe to life. While some find the ticket price a bit high, the overall experience is considered educational and unique, particularly for families and school groups. The planetarium also features interactive exhibits and a knowledgeable staff, making it a worthwhile visit for astronomy enthusiasts and those curious about space.

M.P. Birla Planetarium is a fantastic place for space enthusiasts and anyone curious about the universe! Located right beside St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral, this iconic planetarium offers hourly shows in Hindi, English and Bengali each lasting 40-45 minutes.

The shows are engaging and educational, covering fascinating topics like:
* The Solar System ‚Äì A deep dive into planets, moons and celestial bodies.
* Black Holes & Space Mysteries ‚Äì Exploring the wonders of deep space.
* Cosmic Evolution ‚Äì Understanding how the universe has evolved over time.

The dome-shaped theater and stunning visuals make the experience immersive, perfect for both kids and adults. Whether you love astronomy or just want to explore something unique in Kolkata, this place is highly recommended!

Perfect for a family & friends outing, this spot offers an engaging and educational experience for all ages. Plus, it's easily accessible by metro - just a 5-6 minute walk from Maidan station.

With informative shows running every hour, lasting around 30 minutes, you'll be sure to learn something new and have fun! The shows are conveniently available in English, Hindi, and other regional languages. Tickets are priced at Rs 140, which may seem a bit steep, but trust me, the experience is well worth it!

It was a very fulfilling experience with all the things. The show was 30 minutes long and then 30 minutes to roam around to see the exhibition hall and gallery with beautiful pictures and facts displayed. If you are an astronomy enthusiast then it's a must visit. For normal people it's very easy to understand I really liked it.

You can have a Nice experience visiting this place, lots of information about cosmic collision üí•. However choose your show timings. Presently they offer shows in three languages, Hindi, Bengali and English. We choosed a English one starting 2PM which was in English with Subject Cosmic Collision. Very Nice information, however younger kids might need a little help in understanding the show. The exhibition gallery is another attraction which a must visit. And your weight in various planets is a interesting one... every one must check....

The Birla Planetarium in Kolkata is one of the largest planetariums in Asia and a must-visit for astronomy lovers. Built with an impressive architectural design inspired by the Buddhist Stupa at Sanchi, the planetarium offers a blend of science, education, and entertainment. The main attraction is its immersive sky theatre shows, which use advanced projection technology to take visitors on a journey through the stars, planets, and galaxies.

The exhibits showcase models of spacecraft, astronomical instruments, and informative panels on space science, making it a fascinating place for students and curious minds. The seating arrangement inside the theatre is comfortable, and the narration of the shows is available in multiple languages, which helps cater to a wide audience.

Located at the heart of Kolkata near Victoria Memorial, it is easily accessible and surrounded by other cultural landmarks. The Birla Planetarium not only inspires scientific curiosity but also provides a unique experience of exploring the mysteries of the universe in a simple and engaging way.
12 noon - 1 pm.. Show in Bengali language
1 pm - 2 pm... Show in English
2 pm - 3 pm... Show in Hindi... Then continue

I went there to watch the 6 PM English show. The oral experience is very nice and the way it is presented to you is very interesting. Would recommend to anyone who has never seen such thing.
Only problem was the line for the ticket and for entry took several minutes and when I say several minutes, I mean 30 to 40 minutes. Also, The do not except UPI as a form of payment method for the ticket they either accept domestic cards, not even even international ones and cash.

i had wonderful experience here, the day when i visited Kolkata it was soo hot, i got an escape from that busy and noisy surroundings for more than a hour. there was so much information for all the space and universe lovers. i would really love to go back again.‚ù§Ô∏è

placeMetadata.name: General Post Office

sources.snippet: The General Post Office, with Corinthian pillars and a huge dome, is an opulent building that is currently the head office of the postal service.
sources.shortName: Kolkata Street Photography Places, Places for Photography in Kolkata

placeMetadata.description: Neoclassical structure with a high white dome built in the 1860s on the site of a British fort.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The General Post Office (G.P.O.) is a striking neoclassical building with a prominent white dome, originally built on the grounds of a former British fort in the 1860s. It stands as one of the main colonial-era structures in the city, alongside other notable edifices like Writers Building and St. Johns Church. The G.P.O.'s imposing design was created by Walter L. B. Granville and constructed by Mackintosh Burn Ltd.
placeMetadata.address: Netaji Subhas Rd, Fairley Place, B.B.D. Bagh, Kolkata, West Bengal 700001, India

reviews.reviewText:
Ah, the iconic and majestic General Post Office (GPO) of Kolkata ‚Äî not just a building, but the Hogwarts of snail mail! Nestled like a grand old Maharaja at the heart of B.B.D. Bagh, this imposing white-domed beauty has been delivering drama, bills, love letters, and legal summons with equal flair since 1868.

A Post Office With Serious Posture
Designed by Walter B. Grenville (clearly a man who didn‚Äôt believe in subtle entrances), the GPO is a Neoclassical masterpiece, flaunting Corinthian pillars, giant clock towers, and a dome that could give the Capitol Building a complex. It‚Äôs more regal than most palaces and about as efficient as your grandma with birthday reminders.

Walk through its grand colonnades and you're instantly transported to an era where pigeons were considered rivals and the postman was the OG influencer.

Beneath the Glamour, A Bit of Ghost History
Here's a juicy nugget: the GPO was built right over the ruins of the Old Fort William, razed after the Battle of Plassey. A small plaque near the eastern steps marks the ‚ÄúBlack Hole of Calcutta‚Äù ‚Äî yes, "that" infamous dungeon. Now, that‚Äôs some deep post-colonial subtext.

Fun ‚ÄòPost-al‚Äô Facts:
- It‚Äôs the largest post office in India by volume of mail handled.
- The GPO houses a Philatelic Bureau that‚Äôs a haven for stamp collectors, aka the hipsters of the postal world.
- Still operational and elegant, it‚Äôs where the past and present shake hands ‚Äî in triplicate.

Worth a Visit?
Absolutely. Whether you‚Äôre sending a postcard, buying a commemorative stamp, or just gawking at the colonial grandeur, the GPO delivers ‚Äî literally and metaphorically.

Final Stamp of Approval?
The Kolkata GPO is not just about postage ‚Äî it‚Äôs about poise, purpose, and nostalgia sealed in an envelope and dropped into the past. In a world of WhatsApps and DMs, it still stands proud, reminding us that sometimes, a letter in hand is worth two emails in spam.

The oldest post office of India is the Kolkata, GPO. Lovely architecture to look at. Has the operational post office, a cafe, a museum and a collector's paradise here.

I went to check out the museum and was happy to be transferred to the olden times. Lot of old postal stamps, machines and letters to be seen here. It's beautiful and has been donated by people who like and have been collecting stamps/artifiacts for a long time.

There are real telegrams also displayed along with real Post boxes from Chennai used in places of high order like the Raj Bhavan or important areas.

Sweet and simple. Must visit once for people who love history.
The cafe here is nice. Well lit and wel kept. Food is so so but coffee at 50/- was good.

Kolkata GPO - one of the largest post offices in India (by volume) and also one of the best buildings, architectural dome style from the colonial times. The place itself is history.

For stamp lovers, it has a Philatelic Bureau, you can visit on a weekday. Also, drop a postcard to a dear friend in the letterbox outside!

One of oldest post office of India üáÆüá≥. Established during the reigns of British rule in India. It still holds the antique structures and very well maintained till date. Presently, head office of India posts of West Bengal Circle. Staffs are co-operative and helpful. There are 20+ numbered counters, all for different purposes. Out of which 20th Counter is for stamps and 5th counter is for enquiry. Aadhar related works are also done here. Drinking water facility is also available inside.

The Kolkata General Post Office (GPO), located in the heritage-rich area of BBD Bagh, is a true architectural gem and one of the city‚Äôs most iconic landmarks. The majestic building, with its grand white dome, Corinthian pillars, and colonial design, reflects Kolkata‚Äôs historical charm. Inside, the environment is spacious and clean, and the counters are well-managed. Staff were polite and guided me well through the postal process. Apart from its functional role, the place holds great significance for history enthusiasts and photographers. A must-visit if you‚Äôre exploring the historical heart of Kolkata.

It was in celebration at the GPO, marking 250 years completion of the Kolkata General Post Office at service of the people and India Post.

The Kolkata GPO holds the distinction of being India's first General post office, established in 1774 by then Governor General of Bengal, Warren Hastings.

The General Post Office (GPO) building in Kolkata is a stunning example of Victorian architecture. Built in 1868, it features a grand clock tower and a majestic dome. Designed by Walter B. Granville, it's a UNESCO-recognized heritage building and a city landmark..

The museum is divided into two sections, with the top level housing antique textiles, carpets, miniatures of Mughal monuments, and paintings by renowned artist Rabindranath Tagore. placeMetadata.address: 2, Cathedral Rd, Maidan, Kolkata, West Bengal 700020, India

reviews.reviewText:
The Academy of Fine Arts in Kolkata, established in 1933, is a venerable institution dedicated to promoting art and culture. Situated opposite the Victoria Memorial, it houses several galleries showcasing a diverse collection of paintings, textiles, and other art forms, including significant works from the Bengal School of Art by artists like Rabindranath Tagore and Jamini Roy.
Beyond its art collections, the Academy is renowned for its theatre auditorium, a popular venue for plays and cultural performances, including its annual theatre festival. While some visitors note that the infrastructure could benefit from updates, the Academy remains a vital hub for Kolkata's artistic community, hosting regular exhibitions by both emerging and established artists. It offers a valuable glimpse into the region's artistic heritage and contemporary art scene.

The Academy of Fine Arts, located near Maidan in Kolkata, is a truly remarkable institution and one of the oldest fine arts societies in India. Visiting it feels like stepping back in time; the air is thick with history, and every corner whispers stories of Bengal's rich artistic heritage.
The galleries here are a treasure trove, housing an incredible and priceless collection of paintings, textiles, and sculptures, including significant works by the Tagore family. To see such masterpieces firsthand, spanning various eras and styles, is truly inspiring. Beyond the visual arts, the Academy also boasts an auditorium and a conference center, showcasing its role as a vibrant hub for cultural activities in the city.
One of the most delightful aspects is the feeling that time has stopped here. It's a serene escape where you can truly immerse yourself in art and history. Learning about our cultural past through such a beautifully preserved collection is a genuine pleasure. The Academy of Fine Arts is not just a building; it's a living testament to India's artistic legacy, and a visit here is a deeply enriching experience for anyone keen to explore the depths of our heritage.
Best art gallery of Kolkata. Visited multiple times. Contains artwork of Tagore family in the first floor.

‚Ä¢ The Academy of Fine Arts in Kolkata is a celebrated space for visual arts and culture, known for hosting exhibitions, theatre performances, and promoting artistic expression across generations. It has been an integral part of Kolkata‚Äôs cultural identity for decades.

‚Ä¢ üìç Located near Nandan and not far from Rabindra Sadan or Exide More, it is easily reachable via the Rabindra Sadan Metro Station. While not directly beside Nandan, it's a short and easy walk from there, nestled in a lively and artistic corner of the city.

‚Ä¢ I visited the Academy of Fine Arts for the first time yesterday with my cousins, and we explored both a painting and photography exhibition. It was a memorable and inspiring experience, offering a calm and unhurried space to truly appreciate the works on display. üé®üì∏

‚Ä¢ The exhibitions featured a diverse mix of styles and themes, from bold contemporary pieces to emotional, narrative-driven photography. The environment inside was peaceful, allowing us to connect with the art without distraction. The lighting and display arrangements were modest but effective.

‚Ä¢ It‚Äôs also worth noting that there was no entry fee, which makes it even more accessible for anyone interested in exploring art. Despite being a free-entry venue, the experience didn‚Äôt feel lacking in any way ‚Äî it‚Äôs clear the focus here is on substance over flash.

---

Overall: The Academy of Fine Arts is a must-visit for art lovers in Kolkata. ‚ú® If you're looking to engage with meaningful painting and photography in a quiet, thoughtful setting ‚Äî without spending a rupee ‚Äî this is a wonderful place to start.
The atmosphere is really nice and calm.You feel the artistic vibes.You will get the smell the colors of the paint..They always bring new paintings.

With regular stage plays, rotating art exhibitions, and a nostalgic, creative vibe, it offers a deep dive into Bengal‚Äôs artistic soul. While the infrastructure could use some upgrades, its charm and legacy more than make up for it.

The Academy of Fine Arts is not just a venue, but a legacy. Whether you‚Äôre catching a play, browsing an art exhibit, or simply soaking in the creative vibe, it‚Äôs a must-visit for anyone interested in Kolkata‚Äôs cultural heartbeat.

Academy of Fine Arts ‚Äì Beside Nandan, Kolkata

This one is the quieter sibling of Nandan but has its own artistic fire burning. The Academy of Fine Arts is where you go to breathe in brushstrokes, amateur photography, and sometimes some delightfully weird installations.

üìçLocation & How to Reach:
Practically attached to Nandan, just a few steps away. Take the Rabindra Sadan Metro (Blue Line), and once you're out, you‚Äôll reach in under 3‚Äì4 minutes on foot. Can‚Äôt miss it‚Äîit's tucked beside cultural legends.

üé®Experience:
Visited for a painting and photography exhibition‚Äîand wow, it was surprisingly impressive. The layout was simple, nothing OTT, but the artworks had depth. You could just walk in (no entry fee), take your time, and let the silence of the halls do the talking.

The vibe is peaceful. No rush, no loud tour groups, just people slowly taking in the art. And hey, you don‚Äôt need to be an art snob to enjoy it. It‚Äôs raw, real, and very Kolkata.

placeMetadata.description: British East India Company headquarters designed in 1777, now West Bengal state government offices.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Writers' Building, originally constructed in 1777 as the headquarters of the British East India Company, now serves as the offices for the West Bengal state government. This Greco-Roman landmark has a scandalous history, including its construction and subsequent usage by Governor-General Marquess Wellesley. Situated at the northern end of Dalhousie Square, it was initially used to house junior writers of the East India Company, hence its name.
placeMetadata.address: H8FX+GGJ, Binoy Badal Dinesh Bag N Rd, Lal Dighi, B.B.D. Bagh, Kolkata, West Bengal 700001, India

reviews.reviewText: The Writers‚Äô Building, located in the capital city of Kolkata, is a secretariat building of State Government of West Bengal. It is one of the many heritage buildings situated in Kolkata that brings out the essence of the British East India Company era. Stretched across Lal Dighi, a local water body in the B.B.D Bagh area of Kolkata, it has served as the office of Chief Minister of West Bengal up until 2013.

The iconic Writer‚Äôs Building ‚Äî Kolkata‚Äôs grand old office ‚Äî has been watching history unfold since 1777, making it older than the United States of America‚Äôs constitution! Originally built by the British East India Company to house junior clerks (or ‚Äúwriters‚Äù), this red-bricked giant evolved from a mere workplace into the epicenter of Bengal‚Äôs political drama.
Architecturally, it‚Äôs a stunning blend of French Renaissance and Greco-Roman influences, complete with massive Corinthian columns, arched windows, and statues of Greek gods silently judging the bureaucrats inside. But don‚Äôt be fooled by its regal exterior ‚Äî this place has seen enough action to put a Bollywood thriller to shame.
Most famous is the Chittaranjan Das-led revolution of 1930, when three young freedom fighters ‚Äî Benoy, Badal, and Dinesh ‚Äî stormed the building, assassinated Colonel N.S. Simpson (a ruthless British officer), and fought till their last breath. The spot, now marked as "B.B.D. Bagh," stands as a tribute to their bravery.
Today, the Writer‚Äôs Building is the seat of the West Bengal state government, though its corridors echo with both political power and the occasional ghost story! Yes, some believe the spirits of former clerks still linger, probably waiting for overdue paperwork.
Verdict: A historical gem wrapped in bureaucracy. Pro tip ‚Äî visit during daylight - with the appropriate permissions - for the best view, unless you enjoy ghostly whispers of unfinished files! üèõÔ∏èüìúüëª

Went to the heart of Kolkata after a long time but it always feels great to visit this historical place to see those historical monuments of our city of KOLKATA.
Writer's building now 99% Non operational as the state administration now shifted and controlled from Nabanna, I can see renovation work going on inside the building but that is in very slow pace.. Now only a few departments have their partial operations in Writer's building ( I saw some people came to visit the PWD department)..
Hope , our pride Writer's building will become operational like before very soon and make the Iconic Dalhousie area again super busy ü§û

**Writers‚Äô Building** is one of the most iconic and historic landmarks of Kolkata, located in the heart of **B.B.D. Bagh (formerly Dalhousie Square)**. Built in **1777** during the British colonial era, it originally served as the office for junior clerks or "writers" of the **British East India Company**‚Äîwhich is how it got its name.

The building is an architectural marvel, designed in the **Greco-Roman style** with grand columns, long corridors, and massive red-brick walls. Over the years, several renovations and extensions were made, and the building eventually became the **secretariat of the Government of West Bengal** after India‚Äôs independence.

Apart from its administrative significance, Writers' Building also holds deep historical importance. It was the site of the famous **assassination of Colonel N.S. Simpson in 1930** by three young revolutionaries ‚Äî **Benoy, Badal, and Dinesh** ‚Äî in the fight against British rule. Their bravery is commemorated in the name of the surrounding area: **B.B.D. Bagh**.

Currently, the Writers‚Äô Building is undergoing a major **restoration and renovation project** to preserve its heritage and structural integrity while modernizing its facilities.

For visitors, even though the interiors are not open to the public, the grand exterior, the historic architecture, and its location amidst other colonial-era buildings make it a must-see spot in Kolkata.

The Writers‚Äô Building is not just an old office ‚Äî it stands as a symbol of Bengal‚Äôs colonial past, administrative legacy, and the sacrifices made during India‚Äôs freedom struggle.

Writers' Building is the official secretariat building of the state government of West Bengal in Kolkata, India. It is located in BBD Bagh, formerly known as Dalhousie Square, and is one of the most iconic buildings in the city.

The building was constructed in 1777 and was originally used to house the junior clerks of the British East India Company. It is a three-storey building with a red brick facade and a Corinthian colonnade. The building has been extended several times over the years and now covers an area of over 55,000 square feet.

Writers' Building is a Grade I heritage building and is protected by the West Bengal Heritage Commission. It is also a popular tourist destination and is visited by thousands of people every year.

Here are some interesting facts about Writers' Building:

It is one of the largest secretariat buildings in India.
It is the oldest three-storey building in Kolkata.
It was the site of the first meeting of the Indian National Congress in 1885.
It was also the site of the assassination of Inspector General of Police Colonel N.S. Simpson in 1930.
The building is home to a number of important government offices, including the office of the Chief Minister of West Bengal.
Writers' Building is a significant historical and cultural landmark in Kolkata. It is a symbol of the city's rich history and its vibrant present.

Origin and Purpose:
Constructed between 1777 and 1780, it was initially designed by Thomas Lyon to be the principal administrative office for junior clerks, or "writers," of the British East India Company (EIC).
It was the first three-storied building in Kolkata.
Over time, it underwent numerous extensions and renovations.
Architectural Features:
The building exhibits a Greco-Roman style with French Renaissance influences.
It features a portico in the central bay and boasts several statues, including Minerva, atop the pediment.
The terrace is adorned with statues representing "Justice," "Commerce," "Science," and "Agriculture," flanked by European and Indian practitioners.
The structure is characterized by its red exposed brick facade.
Historical Significance:
The Writers' Building served as the headquarters of the East India Company in Bengal.
It housed Fort William College, which provided training in Oriental languages to writers.
In the 19th century, it became the office of the secretariat of Bengal when Calcutta was the capital of British India.
It is linked to a significant event in the Indian independence movement: the assassination of Lt. Colonel N. S. Simpson by three Bengali revolutionaries - Benoy Basu, Badal Gupta, and Dinesh Gupta. The square surrounding the building was later renamed B.B.D. Bagh in their honor.
Current Status and Renovation:
Since India's independence in 1947, it has served as the State Secretariat and the office of the Chief Minister of West Bengal.
It is currently undergoing a major restoration and renovation project, which was initiated in late 2013 with an estimated cost of US$29 million.
During the renovation, the Chief Minister's office and other government departments temporarily shifted to a building called Nabanna in Howrah.
The restoration process has faced delays and challenges, but work on the project continues.
While entry into the main building is restricted to employees, visitors can admire its impressive exterior.

Kolkata (formerly Calcutta) is the capital of India's West Bengal state. Founded as an East India Company trading post, it was India's capital under the British Raj from 1773‚Äì1911. Today it‚Äôs known for its grand colonial architecture, art galleries and cultural festivals. It‚Äôs also home to Mother House, headquarters of the Missionaries of Charity, founded by Mother Teresa, whose tomb is on site.

Historic Jorasanko has wide roads dotted with traditional Bengali mansions and local markets. It‚Äôs best known for Jorasanko Thakur Bari, former home of Nobel Prize-winning poet Rabindranath Tagore and now a museum displaying Bengal School art and archive materials relating to the poet‚Äôs life and work. Global art and sculptures can be viewed with advance notice at the Marble Palace, a neoclassical estate from 1835.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Kolkata, a city steeped in history and culture, offers a vibrant tapestry of sights that are perfect for capturing unforgettable moments. From the majestic Victoria Memorial, with its stunning white marble fa√ßade, to the bustling energy of the Howrah Bridge, each corner of this city tells a story waiting to be photographed. Whether you're wandering through the colorful chaos of the Mullick Ghat Flower Market or soaking in the serene beauty of the Acharya Jagadish Chandra Bose Indian Botanic Garden, Kolkata is a photographer's dream, blending the old with the new in a way that is uniquely its own.

As you explore the city, you'll discover hidden gems like the James Prinsep Monument, where the architectural elegance meets the tranquil banks of the Hooghly River. The sprawling Maidan, with its lush greenery and iconic landmarks, provides a perfect backdrop for leisurely strolls and picnics. With so many picturesque locations, Kolkata invites you to grab your camera and embark on a visual journey through its streets, parks, and historic sites. So, get ready to explore and capture the essence of this enchanting city!
